Overly technical details on AI models

Why remove: Target audience likely policy/animal welfare folks, not ML researchers.

Extended literature review on animal cognition

Why remove: Might be tangential; better suited to appendix or cited briefly.

Why keep: Supports moral weight arguments, critical for cause prioritization.

Global AI policy recommendations

Why remove: Very broad scope, could detract from grounded animal welfare goals.

answers.answer:
As I think about what could be trimmed to keep this project focused, a few elements stand out. First, creating a polished visual identity right away—like a fancy logo and full brand guidelines—probably isn’t essential at this stage. It would take a lot of time that might be better spent getting the core community up and running. A simple, clean look should be enough for now.
Second, launching monthly webinars immediately could be too much. They take a lot of effort to plan and promote, and without an existing audience, turnout might be low. It might make more sense to hold off until there’s more interest.
Third, putting together a full press kit could wait until the project has some traction. Media outreach is great, but it’s probably more effective once there’s content and engagement to show.
Fourth, building a huge resource library could feel overwhelming, both for me to maintain and for people to navigate early on. Starting small and growing it over time might work better.
Finally, mapping out a detailed content calendar from day one could be premature since I don’t yet know what topics will resonate most. Staying flexible and adjusting as I learn more will likely be more useful.
Even so, there are two pieces I’d really want to keep. One is the resource library. Having a core set of helpful materials from the start will make the community feel credible and give people a reason to come back. The other is running webinars, even if they’re simple. Live sessions are great for building connection and helping people feel like they’re part of something active. They can also help surface engaged members who might contribute more later on.
Overall, simplifying some parts will help me focus on what really matters: creating value for early members and building momentum.

1 | Elements that could be trimmed
AI social-media snippets
• Distracts from core legal drafting focus.
• Generic AI tools already supply tweet-style copy.
• Risk of tone-deaf messaging or misinformation harming credibility.

Polling & voter-sentiment dashboard
• Reliable district-level polling on animal issues is scarce or paywalled.
• Turning raw numbers into usable insights demands expert analysis.
• Ordinances routinely pass on solid precedent and coalition work alone.

Volunteer micro-task suggestions (≤10 min jobs)
• Requires sophisticated task-parsing and priority logic.
• Could clutter the Progress Hub if poorly ranked.
• Similar functionality exists in project-management apps.

Cross-movement alliance playbooks
• Extensive research and continual updates needed to stay relevant.
• Strategy content feels blog-like rather than product-core.
• Easier to link out to partner NGO resources.

Bite-sized strategy tutorials
• Producing high-quality lessons is almost a separate micro-course.
• Seasoned advocates may skip; beginners might prefer webinars.
• Development time siphons focus from the “draft → enact” loop.

2 | Two features worth defending
Volunteer micro-task suggestions
Why keep it:

Activates idle supporters. Converts five-minute windows into real progress, expanding movement capacity.

Creates a data flywheel. Each completed micro-task (e.g., verifying a citation) improves the shared ordinance database.

Low UI cost. Essentially a filtered view of existing checklist items—high impact without a new surface.

Equity booster. Bite-sized work lowers barriers for people with limited time, disabilities, or caregiving duties.

AI social-media snippets
Why keep it:

Bridges policy and public pressure. Even flawless ordinances stall without community buzz; localized snippets spark engagement instantly.

Speeds over-stretched advocates. Automates the most time-consuming 50 words of any campaign day.

Keeps framing consistent. Pulls from the same precedent database, ensuring facts and tone align with legal strategy.

Differentiates Pawlicy Pal. Competitors end at legal text; adding comms tools positions us as a full campaign platform with minimal extra engineering.

KEEP : Multi-label Frame Classification

Media narratives often combine frames (e.g., morality + economics, or human interest + conflict).

Allowing only one frame risks oversimplifying the nuance in coverage and could skew GPT’s training signals.

Multi-label support mirrors real-world ambiguity and helps advocates recognize layered framing tactics.

Even if technically complex, I can limit it in scope (e.g., allow up to two frames max) and still preserve meaningful insight.

It's especially helpful when comparing ideological framing strategies.

 KEEP: Toolkit for Advocacy Use
This project is not just academic, it aims to serve practitioners.

The toolkit helps translate findings into real-world utility, especially for under-resourced groups.

It strengthens the “so what?” of your project and increases post-sprint impact.

Doesn’t need to be polished or complete, can be a draft format, like an FAQ, prompt examples, or best practices.

It’s a strong deliverable to showcase during the final presentation.

Determining final presentation format
Deciding whether to use PPT, PDF guide, interactive framework, etc., can wait until after we prove the tool’s viability; locking this down now may distract from building and testing features.

Developing exhaustive user-guidelines
A full manual may slow release—lightweight in-app tips or quick-start cheatsheets can suffice for the pilot phase, with a comprehensive guide drafted post-validation.

Wireframing all visualization templates up front
Sketching every screen now risks rework once user feedback arrives; rapid “paper prototypes” or dynamic demos might be more efficient early on.

Build the enrichment pipeline to mine and validate stakeholder attributes from public sources: This could be done in a future stage of the project.

Drafting the project budget and Gantt chart
Detailed financials and full schedule planning, while useful internally, aren’t essential for an initial technical prototype or pilot; they can be relegated to a project-management appendix.
---
Keep:

Testing imports with ChatGPT 4.0
Why keep: Verifying that the system can correctly ingest real-world, varied database formats via an LLM is critical to ensuring broad compatibility and a smooth user experience, skipping it risks building on untested assumptions about input data.

Identifying & selecting visualization tools for map generation
Why keep: Choosing the right libraries or platforms (e.g. D3.js, Plotly, Recharts, Gephi) up front ensures our AI-driven pipeline can seamlessly output high-quality, interactive diagrams. Early tool selection reduces integration risks, informs data schema requirements, and accelerates prototype development by aligning technical capabilities with our chosen map types.

A. Emotional character development (e.g. inner monologue in comic strip)
Simplifying or abstracting the character could leave more room for the ethical framework itself to shine, especially in short-form visual storytelling.

B. Policy memo artefact
The policy memo is well-developed but may be too “document-heavy” for visual-first audiences.

It might be better included as an optional appendix or linked artifact, rather than a core deliverable in a fast-paced, visual toolkit.

C. Low-impact speculative futures cone
Although useful for personal clarity, the futures cone may not offer direct value to the viewer unless explicitly integrated into facilitation or learning materials.

Could risk coming across as abstract unless paired with clear prompts or use cases.

D. Multiple variations of the toolkit (tailored per audience)
While audience segmentation is important, attempting to build multiple formats in the time remaining could dilute impact.

Instead, I could prioritise one well-designed “universal” version and simply recommend adaptations. OR focus on one audience only.

 Blockchain technical explanations
The technical inner workings of blockchain may not be essential to the audience’s understanding.

Could be simplified to focus on the function of trust and traceability, rather than how it works under the hood.

Defending Two Elements I Will Keep
A. Policy Memo (EFTP-2035-04)
Why it stays:

It provides critical worldbuilding: The policy memo anchors the speculative future in bureaucratic realism, making the scenario feel plausible and grounded.

It speaks directly to one of my target audiences—policymakers and system thinkers—who need to see not just what the idea is, but how it could be operationalised in the real world.

It adds credibility and structure to the scenario, demonstrating foresight beyond emotional storytelling.
B. Emotional character moment in comic strip
Why it stays:
The entire project rests on connecting systemic complexity to individual ethical decision-making.

Including a quiet moment—like the character pausing before making a choice—invites the viewer to emotionally place themselves in the story. This is vital for the speculative fiction to engage the viewer.

Potential cuts:
1. Tool Expansion (integration with Teams or Otter)
Not essential to the core value of the project. Best not to overcomplicate the prototype as it may distract from its immediate purpose.
2. Automated transcription (or recording) of business meetings
While it could be a helpful feature, it is not central to the tool’s core purpose: empowering advocates with strong, data-driven arguments. Additionally, it may introduce challenges rather than solve them: particularly around data privacy, consent, and the potential reluctance of businesses to allow recordings.
3. Company-specific tailoring in prototype
Whilst tailoring insights for specific companies adds value to the prototype, it would require more time and access to real business data. In this instance, sample data and hypothetical cases may be enough to validate the tool's core utility.
4. Full stakeholder interviews
They would be valuable, yet take time to schedule and analyse. At this stage, we can replace full stakeholder interviews with assumptions and feedback.
5. Tool branding or naming ("PlantShift AI")
I liked the idea of adding a specific branding and settle on a name for the tool to enhance storytelling, but I recognise is not a priority at the prototype stage and could take away energy from focusing on functionality.

To keep:
1. Automated presentation output (generating slides/presentations)
Reasons to keep:
- Valuable as it helps overcome a common barrier for advocates: limited time and communication design skills.
- Translates insights into ready-to-use material for business stakeholders, increasing the chances that insights will lead to action.
- Adds a layer of professionalism and real-world usability that differentiates the tool from being “just a database.”

2. Business-focused, data-driven advocacy support format
Reasons to keep:
- This tool fills a key gap in the advocacy space by helping campaigners influence corporate decisions through financial, market, and operational insights.
- It supports strategic B2B conversations, not just public messaging - positioning plant-based expansion as a business opportunity, not just ethics.
- Distinctly differentiates the tool from others in the space like Open Paws’ tool by focusing on internal persuasion, decision-making

Candidates for Removal (and why):

1. Direct Human-in-the-Loop CAPTCHA Resolution

Reason: Adds significant operational complexity, human dependency, and cost. Slows processing, incurs fees. For MVP, focus on simpler anti-scraping (proxies) for broader sites; defer this until critical for highly protected sources.

2. Custom Web User Interface (UI) for Data Display

Reason: Substantial front-end effort, diverting resources from core data pipeline. Initially, use database console or pre-built tools. Proves data capabilities without UI overhead, accelerating MVP.

3. Real-time Sentiment Analysis of Extracted Articles

Reason: Adds computational complexity and API costs. Nuanced, prone to bias, requires careful model validation. For initial phase, core extraction and basic filtering suffice; progressively add sophisticated AI.

Defending Core Components: Why They Are Vital
Despite streamlining arguments, certain elements are vital to "AI for Animals" project success and cannot be cut.

1. Custom Web User Interface (UI) for Data Display

Defense: UI is vital; it transforms raw data into actionable intelligence for advocates/politically active. Without intuitive UI, data is inaccessible. It's the primary gateway for user interaction, search, and insight, making project value apparent and enabling rapid identification of policy discussions for strategic action.

2. Real-time Sentiment Analysis of Extracted Articles

Defense: Sentiment analysis is vital for elevating the project to intelligent advocacy support. Understanding tone and reception of animal issues is crucial. It enables advocates to quickly identify opportunities (positive narratives) and threats (negative trends). This capability creates "Advocacy Digests" as strategic tools, guiding engagement by highlighting how an issue is being perceived. It's a cornerstone for actionable intelligence.

Project Pitch: Ensuring Animals Aren’t Left Behind in the Age of AI
What happens to animals when we build powerful AI systems that could reshape the world? Right now, the answer is: no one really knows. That’s a problem—because decisions we make today could either lock in neglect, or build a future where animal welfare truly matters.

Our project tackles this overlooked issue by asking: How can we make sure animals are ethically considered before transformative AI arrives?

To answer this, we reviewed expert perspectives from AI safety, animal welfare, and effective altruism communities. We identified “time-sensitive” interventions—things we should act on now, while AI norms are still forming. These include:

Making sure animal welfare is represented in AI training data

Including animals in future-focused ethical guidelines and policy frameworks

Supporting early collaboration between AI labs and animal advocacy groups

We also explored how future AI systems might impact animal lives, such as through lab-grown meat, wildlife monitoring, or even direct policy advising. Our approach blends research, stakeholder interviews, and scenario planning to imagine how emerging technologies can help—not harm—non-human animals.

What’s next? We plan to publish a brief and host a community workshop to get feedback and grow momentum. But we need your help.

Call to action:
If you're working on AI, ethics, or policy—or simply care about sentient beings—fill out our interest form by Friday to join the feedback group or pilot discussions. Together, we can ensure animals are part of the future we’re building.

answers.answer:
What is the hardest part to explain simply?
The hardest part is articulating how decisions in AI governance today can shape long-term outcomes for nonhuman animals—especially when these effects are indirect, speculative, or system-level.

What do you predict will be the hardest question to answer from a critic? How would you respond?
Critics may ask, “Why focus on animals when AI already poses serious risks to humans?” I’d respond that moral circle expansion is not zero-sum; incorporating animal welfare early is tractable, low-cost, and prevents value lock-in that excludes billions of sentient beings.

Who is your target audience & what do they care about?
My main audience includes AI governance researchers, effective altruists, and ethical policymakers. They care about reducing large-scale suffering, ensuring the safe deployment of AI, and identifying overlooked areas with high expected impact.

How might your pitch need to be adapted or tailored for them?
Since this audience is familiar with longtermism, existential risk, and AI policy, the pitch should emphasize how animal-inclusive governance builds on those principles. Rather than introducing new moral frameworks, I connect our project to familiar concerns like value alignment, institutional lock-in, and neglectedness.

What difficulties or doubts might they have about your project, & how would you address these proactively?
They might doubt the practical relevance or urgency of animal-focused governance interventions. I’d counter this by highlighting feasible entry points—like improving dataset standards, institutional ethics norms, or red-teaming AI systems for animal harm risks—that align with their existing policy agendas.

How does your project advance your career goals?
The project strengthens my profile at the intersection of AI governance and ethical policymaking. It develops my ability to address neglected cause areas, design actionable policy interventions, and think critically about moral inclusion in long-term institutional design—skills central to my future work in global priorities and AI policy.

Artificial intelligence is advancing rapidly, yet the voices of animals are almost entirely absent from its development. The few individuals working on AI for animal welfare are isolated across disciplines and geographies. Think of it as a public infrastructure for coordination, knowledge-sharing, and building the field of animal-inclusive AI.

We also created core infrastructure for researcher profiles, project tagging, and a secure dataset submission process. Our next step is to refine the platform based on feedback, expand our outreach across Asia and other underrepresented regions, and prepare for a public beta launch in late 2025.

2-Minute Pitch
The Problem
When cities grow, animals are often left behind. Urban policies rarely consider animal welfare, leaving advocates struggling to push for changes like bird-safe building codes or humane urban wildlife control. They lack access to the legal data, local precedents, and strategic guidance needed to draft effective, tailored proposals - and that gap stalls progress.
Our Approach
We’re creating Pawlicy Pal, an AI-powered tool designed to help animal advocates and urban planners draft stronger, locally-relevant policies. Pawlicy Pal analyzes city ordinances, environmental data, and precedent-setting policies to generate custom policy language, strategic framing advice, and real-world examples. Whether someone wants to propose non-lethal rodent control, bird-friendly building regulations, or zoning changes to support animal sanctuaries, our tool helps translate good ideas into actionable, politically viable proposals.
Impact & Next Steps
So far, we’ve developed an early prototype of Pawlicy Pal, conducted user interviews with advocates and stakeholders, and created wireframes for the tool’s design. Through this research, we’ve identified key policy areas where cities can make meaningful change and pinpointed the core features our tool must deliver to be effective for users in practice.
Our next step is to refine the prototype for a pilot city, working directly with local advocates to test real policy scenarios. This will help us strengthen our tool and ensure it’s both usable and effective in the hands of changemakers.
Call to Action
We’re looking for advocates, urban planners, and city officials to join our pilot program launching this fall. If you care about building animal-friendly cities, sign up to help us test the beta tool and shape its development. Together, we can make sure animals aren’t just managed - they’re prioritized.
Pawlicy Pal - "Building Cities Where Animals Belong"

It can be used to detect diseases early on, identify when animals are hungry and respond accordingly, and better help farmers understand when farm animals experience pain, stress, or discomfort. Furthermore, we believe that much more can, and should, be said about what solutions will address these risks, and the practical steps that can be taken to resolve these issues.

What is the hardest part to explain simply?
The idea that animals’ lives can be translated into data in a meaningful way—like “suffering scores”—without reducing their experiences to something clinical or desensitised,  is complex and emotionally charged.

What do you predict will be the hardest question to answer from a critic? How would you respond?
 “Isn't this just another layer of green-washing, giving consumers a false sense of morality?”
A: It's a valid concern—and exactly why blockchain and PLF tech matter. The system I explore is designed to expose truths, not obscure them, and give consumers verified, tamper-proof information to reflect real conditions.

Who is your target audience & what do they care about?
My primary audience is all consumers, but especially those who are ethically minded, educators, and food systems thinkers who care about transparency, sustainability, and animal welfare—but may feel powerless to make informed decisions in an opaque system.

How might your pitch need to be adapted or tailored for them?
They already understand the emotional stakes of animal ethics and climate impact, so the pitch should focus less on “why it matters” and more on showing how this future is possible and actionable through existing technologies and tools they already use (like QR codes, food labels, consumer scores)

What difficulties or doubts might they have about your project, & how would you address these proactively?
They might doubt whether consumers would actually change their behavior when confronted with this information, or whether producers would allow this level of transparency. I’d address this by referencing existing signals—like carbon labelling, cage-free shifts, or QR code traceability—that show people do make different choices when systems support them.  There is room for concern still about desensitising effects of frequent exposure to content

How does your project advance your career goals?
This project deepens my work at the intersection of ethics, systems thinking, and innovation. It strengthens my storytelling toolkit for public interest tech and showcases how I can translate emerging technologies into emotionally resonant, policy-relevant futures—skills I want to use in animal welfare, AI ethics, or effective altruism sectors.

answers.answer:
AI has the potential to revolutionize animal welfare, and this is a quickly growing field. However, since this field is so new, it can be challenging to connect with professionals in the field, and there is no central source of information. Research in this field can have a wide range of positive effects, from improving farmed-animal welfare to understanding your pets. In this type of research especially, citizen science is extremely important, and it is important to have a way for citizen scientists to get involved.

That’s why we’re creating People in AI, a directory of research at the intersection of AI and animal welfare. At its core, it will be a place for researchers and citizen scientists to collaborate. We will have a directory of researchers and projects, which people can filter by topic, allowing participants to find more relevant research happening in the field; and we will have a forum where researchers can put out calls for citizen scientists. This forum would also serve as a place to ask questions and exchange ideas and feedback. We are also hoping to eventually expand the platform to include additional features, such as data sharing, mentorship programs, and online events.

Ultimately, we hope this will facilitate greater collaboration in the field, and connect citizen scientists with researchers who could use their data. We have not found any databases with this scope and the ability to communicate directly through the platform, and by filling this niche, we will help to ensure that AI and animal welfare research reaches its full potential.

We are still in the early stages of developing the project; we have a basic website design, but we are still working on the legal aspects before we can publish the website. We are also working on securing funding to cover the website domain, any fees for consulting with a lawyer, and any software we would need to purchase to create and run the directory.

In the meantime, we are collecting feedback on the project, as well as testimonials to promote the project and support our funding applications. If you’d like to support us, please fill out our feedback form, and if you are willing, you can also provide a testimonial in a separate form. Please also send me a message if you would like early access.

answers.answer:
1. The hardest part to explain simply is the way we would collect and store information on the website, and the legal details that we are still working out.
2. The hardest question to answer is what the platform will achieve before it has many participants, since the directory relies on a large number of people using the platform. I would respond by saying first that we hope to start out with a solid group of people, since we are connected in some way to the major groups in this field and plan to contact as many people as we can and offer early access. Additionally, once we get the word out, those who are most interested in collaborating or reaching out to a wider audience are the most likely to use our platform.
3. The target audience is academic researchers, research organizations, independent researchers, and citizen scientists. Researchers care about having access to information, conducting their research effectively, and securing funding; citizen scientists care about supporting research.
4. For citizen scientists, the pitch could be adapted to emphasize how it would make their role easier (and for those who are hoping to advance their career, that it would provide relevant opportunities). For researchers, it could be adapted to list more specific ways it could aid them in their work.
5. Researchers might have concerns about data security. To address this, I will note that we currently will not have sensitive data stored on our site; information about current research projects will only be what researchers choose to share. Additionally, we will be consulting with a lawyer about our data policies.
6. I am hoping to go to graduate school and research interspecies communication as part of my studies. Since it is a relatively small field that greatly benefits from central places for communication and from citizen science, I believe it’s directly relevant to the field.

2-minute pitch:
Hi everyone, I’m working on a project called Plantshift AI: a no-code prototype designed to support animal advocates and consultants working with companies to expand their plant-based offerings.
Here’s the problem:
Even though interest in plant-based products is booming, many businesses – from restaurants to food manufacturers – are still hesitant to shift, or don’t prioritise a change in this direction. Why? Because they prioritise profit and risk reduction. Without strong, data-backed cases showing that plant-based innovation is profitable and in demand, they’re unlikely to act and prefer to play it safe within the ways they’ve always done things.
That’s where Plantshift AI comes in.
This tool is designed to help advocates and consultants in the field build compelling, profit-oriented business cases. It will provide real-time, tailored insights – including market trends, consumer demand, regional and demographic data, and examples of what competitors are doing successfully. All of it backed by reliable and provable sources.
The prototype I’m presenting in Lovable is a simulation of what the real tool could look like. The final version would be a website-based AI system, with a chatbot-style interface where the user inputs information from business conversations – like a company’s concerns or questions – and the tool responds with relevant, data-backed insights.
The engine behind it would draw from a curated dataset of validated sources and studies, along with manually added industry insights. One standout feature: it could automatically generate polished presentation slides or summary reports, making it easier to follow up with companies quickly and persuasively.
What’s next?
I’m now looking for feedback from people working in this space – animal advocates, plant-based consultants, corporate campaigners – to test and refine the concept.
If this sounds like something you’d use or want to shape, please fill out my short feedback form by Friday. It only takes 5 minutes, and your input will help guide how Plantshift AI takes shape:
https://forms.gle/vDuH84Z6RYom8zsB7
Thanks so much!

Link to the tool preview: https://preview--veggie-biz-boost.lovable.app/

answers.answer:
1. Explaining what type of data/presentation my tool can deliver in real time given that I'll only be presenting a prototype that can't run on real data or pull from real sources. It can be difficult without sounding overly technical or abstract.
2. The hardest questions might be around the reliability and objectivity of the responses/data provided.
To address this concern, the tool will draw from validated, regularly updated sources like GFI reports, market trend databases, and custom surveys from advocates in the field. It will also provide the source of the information. It’s designed to be curated and transparent, with the option to manually update data sets as needed.
3. Animal advocates working in corporate engagement, consultants, NGO staff. They care about effectiveness, credibility, efficiency, and tools that help them influence companies more persuasively and at scale.
4. Since they already understand the value of data in advocacy, the pitch should focus on how this tool makes their work easier and more impactful by emphasising practical features and real-world applications rather than abstract AI capabilities.
5. They may doubt whether this tool can generate higher quality insights than a generic AI chatbot drawing from the wide web and whether it’s worth investing time learning a new system. I’d address this by highlighting that this tool draws from a carefully curated and purpose-specific dataset, including niche academic papers and insights that might be too specialised or under-represented in mainstream AI like ChatGPT. Additionally, its ability to turn these insights into tailored, presentation-ready outputs adds significant value, saving advocates time.
6. As an animal advocate with experience in corporate engagement, I’ve seen first-hand the challenges addressed by this tool. While my current role is broader, it still aligns with this mission and looking ahead, I hope to establish my own consultancy focused on supporting plant-based transitions. This tool directly supports that vision, offering a foundation for a service I could scale and refine as part of my future practice.

answers.answer:
What is the hardest part to explain simply?
The hardest part is often how AI can really “understand” complex, nuanced conversations about animal welfare like detecting sarcasm or differentiating between criticism of factory farming versus general animal rights sentiment. AI is not magic; it is statistical pattern recognition. Explaining this balance between AI’s power and its limits in plain terms can be tricky but important to set realistic expectations.
What is the hardest question a critic might ask?
Which question is that? How do you know this tool will actually improve campaigns or policy outcomes and not just produce more data?
How would I respond? Great question. The goal is not just more data but actionable insights. We design the platform around the needs of campaign teams providing clear summaries, timely alerts, and trend predictions proven by studies to increase campaign impact by twenty to fifty percent. We also plan early user testing with real advocacy groups to iteratively improve usefulness and measure impact on their outcomes.
Who is your target audience and what do they care about?
Primary target audience is animal advocacy groups and campaign teams in Latin America initially and later similar groups in Asia. What they care about are limited budgets, accessible and affordable technology, timely insights that can help them run more effective campaigns and language and local context relevance.
How might your pitch need to be tailored?
For advocacy groups focus on practical benefits save time, spot opportunities, respond faster. For funders or partners emphasize impact potential and cost-effectiveness. For tech collaborators highlight the AI innovation and open-source opportunities. Build on their existing knowledge of campaigns and storytelling showing how data and AI amplify those strengths.
What doubts might they have and how to address them?
Doubt number one is will this be too complicated or expensive? Answer: We prioritize user-friendly design and are seeking funding to subsidize costs making it accessible even to small groups. Doubt number two is can AI really understand the nuances? Answer: We are fine-tuning models on local language and sector-specific content plus incorporating human feedback loops for continuous improvement.

answers.answer: Radical scientific advances in AI-assisted human-animal communication, biohybrid robotics,and digital sentience are expected to bring forward a host of novel entities that blend the non-human Animal and the Machine to varying degrees: from conversing animals, to biomachine hybrid robots, to digital minds. This study conceptually investigates a path as per which these future extraordinary entities could spiral into monsterization, especially among Western cultures. Specifically, this proposed “cascade of monsterization” begins at the perception of these extraordinary, novel entities as abominations or aberrant entities vis-à-vis the ostensible natural order. It continues with the displacement of those aberrant entities into forced and prolonged liminality, which can then almost effortlessly lead to their monsterization by rendering them hostile towards the Human, thereby justifying their extermination. The cascade of monsterization ends with their potential exploitation as folk devils in moral panics, in which the hegemonic order gets bolstered by means of their persecution. Given the detrimental effects that any of these stages of the cascade can have on the aforementioned entities, alongside the vested interests of actors in pushing them through it until the very end, it is argued that effectively breaking this cascade requires obstructing the perception of those entities as aberrant ones in the first place. A promising starting point for such an intervention is discussed, in light of the existential psychological complications involved in a worldview revision whose target has a core role in a worldview’s configuration.

answers.answer: A common problem in research is tedious, busy work. My project works to reduce busywork for the Stanford Humane and Sustainable food lab with an AI tool for data labelling. The script I wrote takes messy restaurant order data, gives it to Gemini, and returns clean labels for each item, so that it's clear whether the item is vegetarian, vegan, or meat based (with fish, chicken, or red meat). With the tool, no one has to manually go through all the items and sort them by hand. The data is ready for data analysts to look for trends.so they can determine if restaurants sell more plant based items when they're present on their menu, therefore reducing meat consumption and animal suffering. If you'd like to donate to support this and other similar research, visit the website here: https://www.foodlabstanford.com/give

answers.answer:
1. What is the hardest part to explain simply?
It’s hard to explain the nuances of the restaurant data and why we need it labelled. I have a simple framing of the problem when I’m telling people briefly, but it’s more complicated than it sounds because the data is of orders from restaurants, with modifications and typos, and without ingredients lists for many things. I think I could make that more clear.
2. What do you predict will be the hardest question to answer from a critic? How would you respond?
A question I’ve already received: Could there be more sales of vegan items at these restaurants because more vegans go to them?
This is difficult to answer because I’m not the one making decisions for the lab, so I don’t know many of their long term plans to control for these sort of issues. Probably the best way to respond would be to talk to my advisor about that and understand the project better.
3. Who is your target audience & what do they care about?
The target audience for the script is Stanford researchers, but maybe the script could somehow be adapted for researchers in general or I could make new scripts for others tailored to their specific data/scenarios. 
4. How might your pitch need to be adapted or tailored for them? (e.g. What do they already know & how can you build on that?)
To make this pitch more tailored to researchers in general, I could probably make it more of a pitch about my own ability to optimize tasks with AI, and the ask at the end could be for them to contact me if they would like me to work with them to automate monotonous tasks in their labs.
5. What difficulties or doubts might they have about your project, & how would you address these proactively?
I haven’t yet solved the problem very effectively. The code still has a lot of issues and returns some hallucinated results. 
I could work more on optimizing my prompts to Gemini to reduce hallucinations, and put checks into the code to delete weird responses when they occur and prompt the AI again to retry.
6. How does your project advance your career goals?
It's giving me useful experience working with AIs in data analysis, and connections with people in the animal welfare research field.

answers.answer:
Want to change minds without starting fights?
Have you ever come across a comment from an animal advocate that made you think,
 “This is why people don’t listen to us”? 
Or are you an advocate and you’re beyond frustrated that your comments get others’ attention, but fail to convince them to the cause?
Examples:
“If you’re not vegan, don’t call yourself an animal lover.”


“If you own a dog, you exploit animals. Period.”


“Vegetarians are just as bad as meat eaters—maybe worse.”
You have health struggles on vegan diet? You’re just not putting enough effort, and now looking for an excuse to abuse animals again!


Animal suffering is an emotional topic—and it should be.
 But when we speak from anger or pain, it’s easy to lose sight of what actually helps animals.
 To be effective, we sometimes have to stay cool-headed and focus on the message that will create the most change.

A smarter way to speak up
I created a tool to help.
 It’s an AI messaging assistant for animal advocates, grounded in behavioral science and persuasion research.
 You paste in a comment—or your draft reply—and it suggests a version that’s more persuasive, less alienating, and better suited to your audience’s likely mindset.
 It helps you say what you actually mean to say—in a way that people can actually hear.

The Impact
The assistant is now a working prototype, and early feedback has been positive.
 I’ll continue testing it with advocates, improving how it handles tone, audience type, and nuance—and I’ll keep expanding the behavioral research library it relies on.
 The tool can help even home-based advocates become more persuasive—so we can fight animal suffering faster, together.

✅ Call to Action
Want to change minds without starting fights?
 In the next couple of days, please use this link to test the tool: https://behavioral-advocate-tool-gbbscmnjuotofakuna9l9v.streamlit.app/
 You can provide feedback if you’d like—but even just trying it out helps, as I’ll have a bigger pool of replies to assess and improve.

answers.answer:
1. That this is not just general AI but but drawing from specific behavioral science techniques.
2. A critic might ask, “Isn’t this just manipulating people?” or suggest that tailoring the message too much compromises authenticity. I would respond by saying that persuasion is already part of every conversation, and this tool helps advocates communicate more effectively and ethically, without misleading: just framing their values in ways others can hear.
3. My target audience is animal advocates—especially those engaging online, whether individually or within organizations. They care about reducing animal suffering as quickly as possible, and could be interested in a tool that can make their outreach more effective and less emotionally exhausting, ultimately reducing burnout. 
4. Many of them are already familiar with the emotional difficulty of advocacy, so I build on that shared experience rather than explaining it from scratch. I aim to use emotionally honest language and avoid coming across as critical of their passion, instead I frame the tool as something that supports and empowers their existing efforts.
5. Some might worry that the tool will “water down” their message or make them sound too soft. I’d address that by emphasizing that it doesn't censor their values—it helps frame them in ways that reduce defensiveness and increase the chance of actual change, which aligns with their ultimate goal of helping animals. Others may worry about AI being too generic or mechanical; I’d highlight that the assistant is trained and fine-tuned on real-world advocacy language and grounded in research, not just general chatbot behavior.
6. It let's me learn use of new tools, putting my idea into action. It creates a project into portfolio and opens up a way for future colaboration.

answers.answer: The scale of animal suffering is staggering - billions suffer in factory farms and trillions more in the wild. As artificial intelligence advances toward transformative capabilities, it creates both tremendous opportunities and risks for animals. Without deliberate inclusion of animal interests in AI development, we risk creating systems that perpetuate or even amplify this suffering. While a small but growing AI x Animals field has emerged, focusing on critical concerns like AI value alignment and the potential spread of wildlife suffering to other planets, there's a significant lack of strategic direction. Despite increasing recognition and willingness to work on these issues, the field needs clearer guidance on where to focus limited resources. We've developed a first attempt at a "work-in-progress" research agenda that examines the intersection of AI safety and animal welfare. Our agenda aims to identify key differences between AI Safety and AI x Animals work, explores critical decision points that determine which field might have greater impact, maps the current landscape of interventions and research, and prioritizes specific research questions to advance the field. We've reviewed the limited existing literature and mapped priority questions based on input from those interested in AI x Animals, hoping to build a helpful framework. Our tentative plan provides structure, but we recognize the need for further development to refine our research questions, provide preliminary answers where possible, develop concrete recommendations for researchers and advocates, and think of pathways for collaboration between AI Safety and animal advocacy communities. If you're interested in AI x Animals or knowledgeable about AI Safety, please review our current research agenda document by August 2nd and provide feedback on potential blind spots in our analysis, the tractability of our recommendations, and how our observations could be translated into real-world impact for animals.

This will help me clear up my thoughts on this to see if I should focus on this path, as well as potentially help other advocates, which could help secure collaboration on volunteer projects in the future, for example.

answers.answer: Every year, millions of birds are captured from the wild or bred in cruel commercial breeding operations, also known as mills, and sold into the global multibillion-dollar wildlife trade for use as “pets." The wildlife trade is driving bird species to extinction and responsible for severe suffering in individual birds. Regardless of whether birds are born in captivity or the wild, birds are wild animals who retain the need to fly, forage, and socialize. Meeting birds’ physical and social needs in human homes is difficult. This report explores whether commercially sold AI robot birds could replace or reduce the number of birds currently suffering in the pet trade.

AI is changing the way animals are farmed. On the surface, it sounds like a good thing. Farmers are using sensors and smart software to monitor animals’ health, spot illness early and cut down on waste. It seems like progress. But in my article for FoodFacts.org, I take a closer look at what this really means for the animals.

Yes, some suffering might be reduced. But AI is also making factory farming even more efficient. It allows more animals to be raised in crowded conditions with less human involvement. When animals are treated like data points on a screen, their emotional and social needs are easy to ignore. The core problem remains: these systems are still built on confinement, stress and exploitation.

I wrote this piece because we need to ask bigger questions. Not just how we farm animals, but whether we should be farming them at all. AI could help us move away from cruelty, but only if we choose to use it differently. Right now, it’s mostly being used to prop up a harmful system.

What I want people to take from this article is simple: we have a choice. There are kinder, more sustainable ways to eat, and they’re already available.

So here’s my call to action. Visit FoodFacts.org this week. Read the article. Try one plant-based meal. Share it with someone. Every small action helps build a future where compassion, not just convenience, guides how we use technology.

That AI can reduce some animal suffering while also making the overall system more harmful. It sounds like a contradiction, but both things can be true at once.

- What do you predict will be the hardest question to answer from a critic? How would you respond?
Some might ask, "If AI makes conditions slightly better, isn’t that a good thing?" I’d say: small improvements don’t fix a fundamentally cruel system. Better tools shouldn’t be used to prolong suffering. They should help us move beyond it.

- Who is your target audience and what do they care about?
The piece is aimed at regular social media and online readers, who may or may not care about animals, but may care about sustainability and the future of food.

- How might your pitch need to be adapted or tailored for them?
They likely already know factory farming is problematic. I build on that by showing how AI might quietly reinforce it, and then offer hopeful, practical alternatives they can act on.

- What difficulties or doubts might they have about your project, and how would you address these proactively?
Some may feel overwhelmed or unsure whether individual choices matter. I try to keep the tone empowering and grounded, showing that small changes are both meaningful and doable.

- How does your project advance your career goals?
This piece strengthens my voice as a vegan advocate focused on tech and ethics. It helps spark public dialogue, builds credibility and brings animal issues into a space where they’re often overlooked.

Digital Minds Welfare Assessment Benchmark: A 2-Minute Pitch

The Problem
Leading theories of consciousness suggest sentience could emerge in complex computational systems—if consciousness depends on information processing rather than biological substrates, AI may already approach subjective experience. 
As AI systems gain autonomy and decision-making power in society, their ethical frameworks become crucial since they may perpetuate harmful biases at unprecedented scales. This creates a double risk: vast digital suffering and AI systems that, as influential actors, may systematically disregard the welfare of sentient beings they create or interact with.

Our Approach
The Digital Minds Welfare Assessment (DMWA) benchmark adapts the Animal Harm Assessment methodology to artificial consciousness. We're creating a comprehensive set of questions spanning diverse scenarios relevant to artificial welfare, evaluated across multiple dimensions critical to moral consideration. AI judge models score responses using the crafted criteria, providing quantifiable metrics for how current AI systems approach artificial consciousness and welfare.

Impact
I've created an initial set of 25 benchmark questions and adapted all evaluation dimensions and judging criteria. Next steps include scaling to hundreds of questions across diverse scenarios, refining our evaluation criteria through expert feedback, and conducting pilot evaluations on current AI models. This will establish the first empirical baseline for how AI systems consider artificial welfare.

Call to Action
I invite you to engage with this critical ethical challenge by exploring the original Animal Harm Assessment paper, and the work of organizations like Compassion in Machine Learning (CaML) and Eleos AI.

I’m addressing the widespread misinformation about animal welfare on public forums like Reddit. These misconceptions—ranging from poor training advice to myths about animal cognition—can shape how people treat animals, often reinforcing harmful behaviors. By tackling misinformation at scale, I aim to promote more compassionate, informed interactions with animals.
I built a two-part system designed to identify and respond to animal welfare misinformation online. First, I analyze Reddit posts from animal-related subreddits using keyword extraction and sentiment analysis to uncover common themes and misunderstandings. Then, I use a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) model, grounded in peer-reviewed articles and trusted sources, to generate respectful, evidence-based replies that aim to correct misinformation in real time.
So far I've been able to identify clusters of keywords in key animal-related subreddits. Also using the OpenAI Responses API I've been able to augment the model with a vectorized embedding of some key scholarly articles which are used to respond to respond to misinformation.

I’m building something new at the intersection of gaming, ethics, and animal advocacy. My goal is to shift culture—one where the next generation of players grows up seeing animals not as loot or landscape, but as lives that matter.  Video games are one of the most powerful cultural tools we have. They shape how millions of people—especially young people—see the world. But when it comes to animals, most games fall short. Animals are usually cast as resources, enemies, or background characters. Rarely do they have agency, emotion, or ethical weight.
I’m launching an incubator for animal ethics-informed video games—a program that supports developers, storytellers, and artists to create bold, emotionally resonant games that treat animals as subjects, not just objects.
The global animal simulator market is growing fast—valued at around $2.5 billion in 2023 and projected to more than double by 2032. But most of that growth is still tied to outdated tropes. We’re creating an infrastructure for a new genre: games that reimagine kinship, rescue, rebellion, and sanctuary through an ethical lens.
Participants in the incubator will:
Get mentorship from game designers, animal ethicists, and AI technologists
Build playable prototypes with narrative, ethical, and emotional depth
Develop pitch decks, trailers, and assets that are investment-ready
We're looking for partners, funders, and creators who want to shape the future of interactive storytelling—where compassion is not an add-on, but the game itself.

Have you ever wondered how to get issues noticed on a national policy level in The Netherlands, but don't know who to reach out to and where to begin? For instance, if you feel very strongly about the lack of transparency in supermarket chains with regards to whether or not the meat products they source were humanely slaughtered, to whom do you reach out to get this issue noticed and push for more humane regulations?

This, along with many questions about how to advocate for improving animal welfare as a citizen in The Netherlands came across my mind during the fellowship. In learning about how to contribute, I have been suggested various ways that can affect positive change for animal welfare such as donating to highly effective charities, working or volunteering for animal advocacy organisations to campaign or lobby, or working in research on alternative proteins or humane interventions for the livestock industry, just to name a few. 

As I weighed these routes, I still found myself asking: "But what about contributing to long-term changes such as changing policies that prioritise animal welfare? I live in a democratic country--shouldn't my government be doing something about this?" I did not come across a lot of information on how to do in my network. 

And that everyone was how my project, an informative 3-part blog series about Dutch policy-making and animal welfare, came to be. Inspired by my curiosity and my belief that information on just about anything should be widely accessible, I wanted to dive into this topic with the hope that I can provide some practical and actionable insights on how to get involved in politics, as someone with zero experience and zero background. 

With these blogs, I hope to inspire people living in The Netherlands to move towards action and start using our political system for change, along side all the other routes.

Pitch Title: AI for Ethical Nutrition – Bridging Data Gaps for Smarter Outreach
India’s hidden hunger crisis isn’t rooted in food scarcity—it’s rooted in protein deficiency, especially among underserved communities. Meanwhile, charities, schools, and plant-based businesses committed to sustainable food systems face a different challenge: the evidence they need is scattered across outdated papers, inaccessible nutrition databases, and region-blind recommendations.
To address this, I’m developing a concept for an AI-powered platform that transforms research and policy documents into clear, region-specific insights. The tool will help advocates and institutions create school menus, outreach programs, and policy proposals that are ethical, affordable, and culturally resonant.
Over the past few weeks, my focus has been:
	• Engaging with stakeholders to identify bottlenecks in nutrition outreach
	• Curating research papers and government documents on protein deficiency
	• Mapping available data sources and surfacing accessibility challenges
	
What’s Next? I’ll continue stakeholder outreach and expand dataset curation, aiming for 10–15 core resources. Technically, I’ll begin designing the architecture for a lightweight retrieval system (MVP) using RAG-lite methodology. This includes embedding text with models like Sentence-BERT and preparing a vector store—starting with one category and simple metadata. The platform will eventually support multilingual queries using Sarvam, a language model trained on Indian context and regional dialects. ( this approach can change based on changing datasets and needs).

Call to Action: If you’re a nonprofit, educator, activist, or nutrition advocate, fill out this 1-minute form by July 31st to join our pilot feedback group: (working on the form)
Let’s co-create an AI tool that reflects your work, your region, and your mission.

Issue: Preventable behavioral issues have become one of the driving factors behind canine surrender in the United States. This results in an inflated population of shelter dogs with significant behavioral issues that are difficult to place with capable homes, and have a subpar quality of life.

My final output for this session is a paper describing the issue I’ve identified, and how AI-assisted tools (in particular a free ‘Doulingo’ like app) could take advantage of theories of cognition and learning to improve caretaker fluency in dog training and communication. This paper is a wide overview of my research and thoughts about this issue and the possibility of AI-assisted solutions, but as I want to continue this research in the future, it may avoid going into significant detail on some of the issues.

answers.answer: Imagine a future where artificial intelligence not only benefits humans but protects animals too. Unfortunately, that’s not today’s reality. In Southeast Asia, AI is rapidly expanding across agriculture, wildlife management, and scientific research. But there’s little transparency on how it’s impacting animals either positively or negatively. Some AI systems are helping: drones to detect poachers, sensors that monitor animal welfare. But others raise red flags: automated slaughter systems with no ethical oversight, or wildlife surveillance tools that could be misused. Right now, there’s no centralized way to track these trends. As a result, policymakers, researchers, and advocates are flying blind. That’s where Sentient Futures comes in. My project is building a public, open access website that maps the real world use of AI and its effects on animals in Southeast Asia. The platform collects case studies, visualizes risks and opportunities, and provides ethical insights for responsible development. It’s inspired by projects like the Animal Rights Map and AI Safety Map but uniquely focused on our region and on animals. Over the past few weeks, I’ve built a working prototype, drafted core content, and identified dozens of use cases in the region. With the right support, this can become a vital tool for journalists, NGOs, students, and decision-makers. Let’s make sure AI evolves with compassion not just code.

There are basically two different groups of people I think could benefit from this tool, so there should be two pitches.

Pitch 1: For Animal Advocates (to get them more politically involved)

Pitch 2: For Politically Active Individuals (to get them more involved in animal issues)

Pitch 1: For Animal Advocates (to encourage political engagement)
Problem: Many passionate animal advocates, while dedicated to direct welfare work or raising awareness, often feel disconnected from the legislative processes that profoundly impact animal lives. This gap limits their collective power to influence systemic change and ensure animal protection laws are robustly debated and enacted.

Pitch 2: For Politically Active Individuals (to highlight animal issues)
Problem: Individuals highly engaged in political discourse and policy often overlook or are unaware of how seemingly broad issues—like environmental policy, land use, or economic development—directly intersect with animal welfare and conservation. This oversight can lead to policies that unintentionally harm animal populations or miss opportunities for comprehensive, animal-inclusive solutions.

Solution: I am developing an automated web scraping and data aggregation workflow using n8n that identifies animal welfare issues and relevant political discussions from various online sources. This tool will provide concise, actionable summaries of political developments affecting animals, empowering advocates to engage more effectively with policymakers and legislative efforts.  The tool will provide automated scores and rankings of political candidates on animal issues.

Career Connection: My work on this project directly supports my career aspiration to bridge knowledge gaps between different advocacy sectors. By learning data automation and information extraction techniques, I am equipping myself to analyze complex policy environments and present compelling, evidence-based arguments that can integrate animal welfare considerations into broader political agendas.

answers.answer:
AI has the potential to radically improve the welfare of farm animals. It can be used to detect diseases early on, identify when animals are hungry and respond accordingly, and better help farmers understand when farm animals experience pain, stress, or discomfort.  But AI also has the potential to significantly worsen farm animal welfare. It could make mistakes and cause great suffering as a result, decrease our empathy and concern towards farm animals, and lead to further intensification and cramped living conditions..
Our paper seeks to address these concerns by identifying the major welfare risks associated with AI enhanced livestock farming, and providing clear, well-researched, and practical guidelines for addressing these risks.
In doing so, we hope to fill in several gaps in the literature. While some papers have already touched on some of the animal welfare risks associated with precision-livestock farming (PLF), little attention has been paid to the risks that stem from AI enhanced PLF in particular. Furthermore, we believe that much more can, and should, be said about what solutions will address these risks, and the practical steps that can be taken to resolve these issues.

answers.question: You can post a link below or write some bullets, but be ready to share your example with the group in our session.
answers.answer: One exciting application of AI in animal welfare is in animal communication, particularly with great apes and cetaceans. An article by The Guardian (2023) highlights the work of the Earth Species Project, which is using machine learning to decode animal vocalizations and behaviors. By training neural networks on massive datasets of animal sounds and interactions, researchers hope to break the barrier of interspecies communication. This could radically shift how we understand and treat nonhuman animals—by granting them a “voice” in conservation, welfare decisions, and habitat protection. If we can better understand how animals express pain, stress, or social needs, we can dramatically improve captive and wild animal care. Moreover, this research challenges speciesist assumptions about intelligence and communication, pushing toward a more inclusive moral circle.

answers.question: Imagine: AI for the benefit of animals.[150 words] If you could solve one major animal welfare & protection issue using AI, what would it be? Try & take on the following questions in your response:What is the problem you're seeking to solve?What is currently being done about it– & why isn't it working?How could AI do it better or do what is not yet being done?
answers.answer:
One major problem I'd like to solve using AI is the mass suffering of animals in industrial farming, especially the failure to detect early signs of pain, injury, or distress in factory-farmed animals. Current solutions rely on periodic human inspections, which are often infrequent, subjective, and limited in scale. As a result, millions of animals suffer in silence from untreated ailments and chronic stress.

AI-powered precision livestock monitoring could change this. Using computer vision and bioacoustics, AI can continuously monitor animal behavior, posture, vocalizations, and movement to detect abnormalities that signal suffering. Unlike humans, AI can analyze thousands of animals in real-time, 24/7. This would enable rapid intervention, improve welfare standards, and hold producers accountable. Moreover, this technology could support stronger regulatory frameworks and inspire public pressure for humane practices. AI here doesn’t just optimize productivity—it can align industrial systems with compassion.

Try & take on the following questions in your response:What is the problem you're seeking to solve?What is currently being done about it– & why isn't it working?How could AI do it better or do what is not yet being done?
answers.answer:
One major problem I want to solve using AI is the lack of real-world data on how AI is affecting animals. Most current conversations are based on assumptions or forecasts rather than direct evidence. While we know how past technologies have harmed animals, especially in factory farms, we do not yet understand how AI is already being used or what its long-term impact will be. This makes it very hard to explain the risks to the public or influence policy and ethical development.

Right now, very little is being done to track or study the impact of AI on animals. Without clear data, most people do not see this as an urgent issue. That slows down action.

AI itself could help by gathering and analyzing data from current systems. Where data is missing, AI could model possible outcomes and risks. This would help us bring animal welfare into mainstream AI conversations and act before harm becomes widespread.

answers.answer: If I could solve one major animal welfare issue using AI, I would focus on improving the welfare of working animals in Nepal, especially equines like donkeys and mules that are essential to rural livelihoods but often face harsh conditions. These animals endure chronic neglect, inadequate veterinary care, and minimal monitoring. Owners, often limited by poverty, lack both awareness and resources to provide proper care. While some NGOs and local governments offer support, these efforts are often scattered, underfunded, and inconsistent, leaving big gaps in welfare. This is where AI could make a real difference. By developing a cooperative, AI-powered mobile app, we could integrate real-time veterinary data, owner-reported feedback, and environmental monitoring. This tool would not just store information but would learn from it, predicting health risks and suggesting timely interventions. Imagine a system where local vets, owners, and policymakers are connected through one platform that flags urgent welfare concerns before they become crises. What excites me most is that this shifts us from reacting to problems toward preventing them. It encourages coordinated action and creates a feedback loop that improves both animal and human well-being. Honestly, if we can make that happen, it would feel like a small but meaningful revolution in both AI and animal welfare.

An example of precision farming:

The article describes how Aquabyte’s AI-powered underwater camera system can count the sea-lice on every salmon that passes the lens. Sea-lice is a big risk both to salmon welfare and to the environment around the sea-pens. Recognising this, Norwegian salmon producers are legally bound to keep track of the sea-lice levels in their pens, and must keep these levels low if they want to expand production.
By using tools such as the Aquabyte system, one can avoid the weekly “manual sampling”: a stressful procedure which involves the fish being netted, anaesthetised and held outside the water. The automated counting is also more precise, which has further benefits, both for fish welfare (e.g., due to fewer unnecessary delousing procedures) and producer output. Regulators accept these automated counts as valid.

answers.answer:
Not the biggest-impact fix, but still worth discussing: Many countries have some decent animal-welfare laws, but still have bad practices. Two related forces may drive this: (1) fines are too small to outweigh profit motives, and (2) inspections are too infrequent because agencies are understaffed and also handle food-safety work. Serious violations usually surface only when NGOs or undercover journalists publish footage.

My proposal to tackle (2)  is mandatory overhead cameras in livestock buildings, feeding computer-vision models that watch for overcrowding, withheld feed or water, rough handling, etc. - i.e., is looking for unlawful practices in production. If the model spots an overstep, it reports to the producer and the relevant authority.

Automated, round-the-clock monitoring would raise the real risk of getting caught, making deliberate abuse and persistent neglect harder to hide. It also gives compliant farms proof for retailers and the public, which can be useful, given how damaging past exposés have been. Face blurring and event-based storage could limit privacy risks. Obviously there are further issues here, something we can discuss in class.

I decided to choose animal abuse, as is a tough problem. It's often hidden, hard to track, and prosecuting it can be a real challenge. Plus, a big part of the issue is a lack of understanding and empathy for what animals go through. While we have laws, shelters, and awareness campaigns, they often struggle with limited resources and changing deep-seated attitudes.

This is where AI could be a game-changer. We can imagine AI that can scan the internet for signs of cruelty, or even systems that monitor animal behaviour and sounds for distress. AI could also help investigators sort through evidence more effectively. And perhaps most powerfully, AI can help build empathy (if we intend to design it this way). For example, like the one in the "Wild Narratives" study, that let you hear a story from an animal's point of view. These kinds of tools can really help people connect and understand.

So, AI isn't just about better detection; it's about fostering that crucial empathy and awareness, helping us protect animals in a more proactive and effective way. Of course, we'd need to be smart and ethical about how we use it.

One issue I’d prioritize solving with AI is animal experimentation in biomedical research and drug testing. Despite growing awareness, millions of animals are still used annually, even though over 90% of drugs that pass animal tests fail in human trials. This stems from systemic biological differences, ethical complacency, and inertia within regulatory systems. While alternatives like organ-on-chip models and computational simulations exist, they remain underutilized due to lack of awareness, validation pathways, and integration across research pipelines.

AI could accelerate this transition by improving predictive modelling of human responses, optimizing organ-on-chip simulations, and identifying when animal data misaligns with human biology. It could also map redundant experiments, aid regulators in assessing risk, and support open-source platforms for data transparency. Crucially, AI can expose the inefficiencies and moral costs of animal testing in ways that are scientifically rigorous and policy relevant. This would then catalyze a shift toward humane, human-relevant science.

Open Paws' innovative AI-powered email outreach system demonstrates how technology is transforming animal advocacy. In their recent pilot program, this fully automated system sent 678 personalized emails to restaurant owners at just 6 cents per email, securing commitments from eight restaurants to expand vegan offerings—all for under $50 total.
The system works by using AI to gather verified email addresses, create personalized messages tailored to each recipient, and continuously learn from interactions to improve future outreach. With no staff or salary costs, every dollar goes directly to advocacy.
Their results suggest remarkable efficiency: potentially saving 25-98 animals per dollar spent, which they estimate is 35-140 times more effective than traditional campaigns. Beyond restaurants, Open Paws has expanded to target politicians and financial institutions, securing commitments including legislation for vegan business tax incentives and support for plant-based school lunches.
This technology exemplifies how AI can dramatically amplify animal advocacy effectiveness through automation and personalization.

For example, if we can show that whales have culture or complex social structures, it could help push for stronger protections, especially around noise pollution.  BUT - we don't do this for many human cohorts, what will make it different for other species? 

There's a real risk of this technology being misused. The article warns about surveillance or exploiting animals in ways we haven’t thought through yet. So it’s important we develop strong ethical guidelines as we go.

I also loved the point that this kind of work could align with Indigenous knowledge. Many Indigenous cultures already understand animals as having their own agency and ways of communicating. AI might finally be catching up with that perspective.

Finally, there’s a call for caution — using principles like “do no harm,” and making sure animal welfare is the priority. Just because we can use AI to study them doesn’t mean we should do it in any way that’s invasive or disrespectful.

The Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services (IPBES) published a global assessment report on how 1,000,000 species are threatened with extinction. This is a huge “wicked” problem so I will narrow down the focus to species like honey bees and bumblebees, which have more than 20,000 species. Pollinators like bees contribute directly to food security and biodiversity, with a third of global food production dependent on bees. Bee populations have been declining globally due to habitat loss, intensive farming practices, climate change and pesticides. 

Some efforts to address the problem include:
* Bans on harmful pesticides (e.g., EU-wide ban in 2018)
* Habitat restoration projects such as wildflower corridors, and improved hive management practices 
* Public Awareness Campaign like the Bee Day from FAO

Why it isn’t enough: Climate change continues to outpace restoration, while pesticide regulation faces resistance from powerful agricultural lobbies. Many conservation strategies lack real-time monitoring and scalability, making it difficult to address the wicked problem with interlinked drivers.

AI is being used for beekeeping: sensors detecting infestation or any unusual activity, the system can automatically feed and water the bees, treat pests and even change temperature and humidity. The startup BeeOdiveristy uses AI to measure pollutants and state of biodiversity using the data bees gather. The World Bee Project Hive Network uses AI algorithms to look for patterns of the beehives so conservationists can better protect them. While it can't replace ecological action or political will, AI can enhance the scale, precision, and effectiveness of current efforts, especially in providing timely data and supporting data-driven policy decisions.

1. Tackling speciesism.
2. Interventions to tackle speciesism tend to focus on appealing to the audience's logic or emotions to induce some sort of change in their moral behavior. However, as predicted by Terror Management Theory, it is possible that speciesism is a type of defense strategy employed by humans to fuel their sense of importance and the meaning of their lives. Attempting to break this strategy by directly opposing it may fuel completely opposite behaviors for strengthening it even more. The underlying cause is a feeling of meaningless of human life that is associated with humans' capacity to envision their future death. (I haven't had time to review the literature on that extensively, but this is indeed based on my past readings in existential psychology).
3. If AI is to do better in helping us tackling speciesism, based on the argument above, it will need to help us better understand and mitigating this phenomenon of humans' implicitly using speciesism as a defense strategy for meaningless, death-bound lives. There are several intervention paths that could use AI, such as using AI to shed more light into the psychological mechanisms underpinning Terror Management Theory and its relation to worldviews and speciesism, or using AI to help humans create meaningful lives through mutually beneficial interactions with animals. A more bold use could be the employment of AI to the scientific search for extraterrestrial life in astronomy and planetary science, since a potential discovery of life beyond Earth might induce an overall paradigm shift in worldviews that encompass the superiority of humans over animals as a shield against meaningless lives, which could in turn render speciesism an obsolete defense strategy.

One major animal welfare issue I would like to solve using AI is the harm and suffering caused in factory farming - particularly that of laying hens, who represent the largest group of land vertebrates exploited for mass consumption. 
The problem:
Billions of laying hens are confined in industrial systems under unethical conditions to meet the global demand for eggs. Despite increasing awareness and the general public recognizing the practice as "inhumane", egg consumption remains high worldwide.
What is currently being done:
Companies like Just Egg have developed plant-based alternatives that mimic the taste and texture of eggs surprisingly well. While promising, these products remain rather expensive, less accessible, and are often perceived as synthetic or niche. As a result, they primarily appeal to higher-income consumers or those already committed to plant-based diets or to a higher consumption of plant-based products. Mass adoption of such products is rather limited and conventional egg consumption continues to dominate - especially in markets where affordability and familiarity are key factors. 
How AI could help:
AI can be used to accelerate the development of better, cheaper, and more appealing plant-based egg alternatives by designing and optimizing plant-based proteins that replicate the functional properties of eggs more closely; engineering crops to produce these proteins more efficiently and at a lower cost; analyzing consumer preferences to inform development that resonates with mainstream audiences (taste, texture, form, and price-point).

I would use AI to better understand animal welfare by helping identify more accurate and meaningful welfare indicators. At the moment, assessments often focus on physical health or productivity, which don’t tell us much about how animals are actually feeling. We miss subtle behaviours or patterns that might reflect stress, comfort or other emotional states, especially across different species or settings. There’s also a lot of variation in how welfare is measured, which makes it hard to compare or improve conditions consistently.

AI could help by analysing video, sound and other data to spot patterns that humans might overlook. It could highlight changes in behaviour or physiology that suggest animals are thriving or struggling, and do so in a way that’s tailored to the species and environment. With better indicators, we could make welfare assessments more reliable, more responsive and more focused on what matters most to the animals themselves.

My hope is that this would also help us be more strategic about where we put our efforts, whether through direct interventions, policy changes, or developing alternatives like new protein sources, so that we can achieve the greatest welfare improvements overall.
