answers.question: One might think that it is more important to work towards the abolition of factory farming altogether, rather than trying to steer the development & regulation of PLF and its associated AI sensor technologies. Abolition versus welfarist development and regulatory oversight: what are the arguments for and against each? In a few short reasoned bullets or sentences write down which YOU think is the more impactful and tractable route to animal protection - and why? (Tip: try and think of at least two bullets from whatever your opposing point of view is)
answers.answer:
Both are certainly imperfect, and entail inevitable suffering.
Abolition has been defended for centuries and doesn’t seem to have dented the industry. I don’t expect continuous pushing for abolition with current strategies is likely in the years to come, though assuming an absence of radical changes in overall societal structures in the decades to come, new strategies like that pursued by Pro-Animal Future might increase our minuscule likelihood of attaining important shifts. Thus, continuing to push in a direction where change doesn’t seem tractable at all seems like a bad idea to me if we wish to prevent the extreme suffering of animals.
However, the correlation between PLF and welfare is important. It’s likely that we’re biased in finding it easier to think of ways a situation could get better rather than worse, and so it’s tempting to think that any change in factory farming will result in net suffering being reduced. Giving the immense impact such technologies could have, there seem to be reasons to be skeptical. Moreover, inventions like Atarraya’s autonomous shrimp farm are a clear indication that PLF will cause net suffering in some sectors. There’s a bit of wishful thinking in betting on PLF, in my view.
My conclusion would be: abolition is currently not very promising, though it could be important in some worldviews to allocate some resources to well-thought out abolitionist projects; PLF could go either way and seems to carry large risks; nonetheless, it makes sense somewhat to focus on PLF, conditional on us believing that it will inevitably become the reality in the future, because it will then be important to try to steer it towards more consideration of animal welfare.

answers.question: For discussion on tractability, see Brown (2024) & Simoneau-Gilbert & Birch (2024).
answers.answer:
Threat 9 : Facilitation of intensive systems is perhaps the first one that comes to mind to animal advocates when they hear of PLF.
Scale: seems large, affecting potentially hundreds of billions of animals per year. However, most of the impact on individuals here will come from what kinds of farming systems are most “optimized” by PLF. Right now, being mostly focused on making the farming of big animals more efficient, we could expect it to lead to the exploitation of large animals becoming more profitable, and replacing that of smaller animals. However, forms of monitoring can also be helpful for smaller animals, who often die in large numbers in factory farms. Right now, this had been less of a central focus, but more “effective” fish, shrimp (see Shrimpox) and insect farms could make the number rise to “thousands of billions of individuals affected”. This seems like the most important question here.
Severity: factory farming at its most intense yet “life-preserving” (without consideration for suffering) level probably causes some of the most intense suffering there is. Thus, PLF causing more animals to live in intensive farms seems very negative for overall suffering.
Tractability: I’m fairly pessimistic about this, though it seems far from impossible, as preventive measures have somewhat of a track record, and there exists a public suspicion of technology mingling in food production in unusual ways. The tractability will depend on exterior factors, like how economically advantageous new PLF-driven factory farming will actually be. If it’s not particularly more profitable, it could be easier for advocates to defend a  moratorium on PLF systems. However, if these do turn out to make intensification much easier and more effective, industry lobbying against such legislation should be expected to be very strong, making animal advocates inaudible.

answers.question: How to measure welfare?Critics worry that the metrics tracked by PLF may not actually correspond with the welfare of animals. How exactly welfare is defined & measured makes all the difference. What risks might there be if there is a “gap” between welfare & the proxy measures that are tracked by PLF?
answers.answer: This feels hard to expand upon to me, as it seems evident that imperfectly tracking welfare will lead to suboptimal care for those who are suffering in ways that are not properly recognized. This is especiall concerning since many forms of suffering don’t cause long-term health risks (like receiving medium-level electric currents). Hence, even meticulous “welfare-tracking” systems could cause immense suffering to animals, without most advocates being clearly aware of it.

answers.question: One might think that it is more important to work towards the abolition of factory farming altogether, rather than trying to steer the development & regulation of PLF and its associated AI sensor technologies. Abolition versus welfarist development and regulatory oversight: what are the arguments for and against each? In a few short reasoned bullets or sentences write down which YOU think is the more impactful and tractable route to animal protection - and why? (Tip: try and think of at least two bullets from whatever your opposing point of view is)
answers.answer:
I'm currently undecided, but I'll pick a side for the purpose of the exercise:

	I (currently) believe that a welfarist approach is likely to be a more impactful and tractable route to animal protection. I base this mainly on the premise that abolition, at least at present, is difficult to achieve given the huge demand and financial support for factory farming. Improvements in welfare as a result of PLF, on the other hand, are far easier to achieve. Some forms of PLF can improve both welfare and productivity (consider PLF which can track and address disease quickly). This makes the interests of farmers and animal welfarists aligned, allowing for the quick adoption of technology which can reduce animal suffering at a large scale. 
	

	Abolitionist objection 1:
	There is no reason to think that PLF will be employed to improve animal welfare. Instead, it will be employed to increase profit. 

	My response:
	Some PLF which is used for profit will also benefit animal welfare (e.g. disease detection). Furthermore, it is much easier to push for welfare enhancing PLF than to push for abolition. 
	

	Abolitionist objection 2: 
	PLF leads to "humane-washing", resulting in people continuing to eat factory farmed animal products, rather than seeing it as the evil it is. This results in factory farming continuing, leading to more animal suffering. 
	
	My response:
Many people are aware of factory farming, yet still continue to eat factory farmed animal products. What is needed in order for people to move away from factory farming is an alternative to factory farmed animal products. Lab-grown meat is one such alternative. When such technology becomes widespread and the cost is significantly decreased, people will be much more likely to move away from factory farming. While we wait for this alternative to arrive, improving animal welfare via PLF is the best thing we can do now to massively decrease animal suffering.

answers.question: For discussion on tractability, see Brown (2024) & Simoneau-Gilbert & Birch (2024).
answers.answer:
Treat 8: Housing and Management Adapted to PLF Instead of Animals

PLF may be more profitable for intensive farming systems than less intensive systems (which tend to be better for animal welfare). E.g. area covered in extensive systems is too large. This could lead to housing conditions that are worse for animal welfare, if doing so makes PLF more effective and thus more profitable. 

Furthermore, if PLF is more profitable for intensive systems than extensive systems, this could lead to intensive systems outcompeting extensive systems even more, which could in turn lead to worse animal welfare. 

Scale - very large: could affect all livestock 
Severity - medium/large: depends on what kind of housing systems are most profitable using PLF. If the most profitable housing systems are barren and cramped, this could of course lead to severe suffering. But maybe larger, more comfortable housing systems could also function okay with PLF, meaning the impact wouldn't be so severe. 
Tractability - fairly tractable. If PLF is more profitable for large corporations than small/family farms, then we can work with small farmers to advocate for restrictions on PLF.

answers.question: How to measure welfare?Critics worry that the metrics tracked by PLF may not actually correspond with the welfare of animals. How exactly welfare is defined & measured makes all the difference. What risks might there be if there is a “gap” between welfare & the proxy measures that are tracked by PLF?
answers.answer: PLF may focus on proxy measures such as health and productivity, rather than on other factors (e.g. animal behavior) that some consider to better reflect animal welfare. This can lead to poor animal welfare. For instance, a PLF system which merely looked at health and productivity may find there is nothing wrong with a caged hen, even if the hen is experiencing intense suffering as a result of stress and boredom. Granted, some of the proxies which PLF looks at do often correspond with welfare (bad health can often result in bad welfare), but not all the time. PLF could be implemented in such a way to track other proxies for welfare (e.g. by analyzing animal behavior).

answers.question: One might think that it is more important to work towards the abolition of factory farming altogether, rather than trying to steer the development & regulation of PLF and its associated AI sensor technologies. Abolition versus welfarist development and regulatory oversight: what are the arguments for and against each? In a few short reasoned bullets or sentences write down which YOU think is the more impactful and tractable route to animal protection - and why? (Tip: try and think of at least two bullets from whatever your opposing point of view is)
answers.answer:
Why focus on PLF instead of abolishing factory farming?
Abolition is the ideal, but PLF is growing fast now. If left unchecked, it could worsen suffering. Regulating PLF is a chance to reduce harm for animals already in the system.

Abolition vs. Welfarist Regulation
Arguments for Abolition:
Tackles the root cause: factory farming is inherently cruel.

Avoids locking in harmful systems with high-tech tools.

Arguments for PLF Regulation (my view):
More tractable: we can influence PLF today, while abolition is politically distant.

Can reduce suffering and raise public awareness.

Sudden abolition would deeply harm families working in these sectors. It’s easy to call for when you’re outside the system. A phased, supported transition is more just and realistic.

My view: Regulating PLF is the most impactful short-term path. It helps protect animals now while allowing time for fair, long-term change.

answers.question: For discussion on tractability, see Brown (2024) & Simoneau-Gilbert & Birch (2024).
answers.answer:
Risk: PLF Reduces Human–Animal Interaction (Threat 6)
Scale:
This risk affects nearly all species in industrial systems where PLF is adopted. As farms scale up, PLF can reduce the time farmers spend observing or caring for individual animals, especially in poultry and pig systems with thousands of animals.

Severity:
Moderate to high. Less human-animal contact can weaken empathy, reduce detection of subtle welfare issues, and increase emotional detachment. Over time, this could normalize animals being treated as data points, not sentient beings.

Tractability:
Medium. We can push for policies that incentivize farmer–animal interaction, or require complementary human welfare checks. But changing norms around labor savings and efficiency will be hard, especially in systems where workers are already under pressure.

Uncertainty / Research Idea:
How does reduced interaction due to PLF affect long-term empathy and animal-oriented decision-making among farmers?

answers.question: How to measure welfare?Critics worry that the metrics tracked by PLF may not actually correspond with the welfare of animals. How exactly welfare is defined & measured makes all the difference. What risks might there be if there is a “gap” between welfare & the proxy measures that are tracked by PLF?
answers.answer:
How to Measure Welfare?
If PLF tracks only easy-to-measure proxies, like feeding rates or movement, but ignores emotional states or social needs, there’s a real risk of false reassurance. Systems might show animals as “healthy” while they are stressed, bored, or in pain.

Key risks of this measurement gap:

Invisible suffering: Welfare problems like fear or frustration won’t be flagged if they don’t show up in the tracked data.

Misleading claims: Farms could be marketed as “high welfare” based on superficial metrics.

Design bias: PLF may push farmers to manage what’s measured, not what matters, leading to further neglect of emotional and psychological wellbeing.

This gap can entrench poor welfare practices under a layer of tech-driven legitimacy, a dangerous illusion of progress.

answers.question: One might think that it is more important to work towards the abolition of factory farming altogether, rather than trying to steer the development & regulation of PLF and its associated AI sensor technologies. Abolition versus welfarist development and regulatory oversight: what are the arguments for and against each? In a few short reasoned bullets or sentences write down which YOU think is the more impactful and tractable route to animal protection - and why? (Tip: try and think of at least two bullets from whatever your opposing point of view is)
answers.answer:
I think it's a reasonable assumption that technology which can optimize a business will eventually get adopted by that business, so it's important for animal welfare advocates to "see the writing on the wall" and prepare for any transformative changes to factory farming as it is currently done, so that we can steer development of these technologies.
I am not sure, concretely, what this steering looks like, though. Focusing on actualizing welfare-positive applications instead of preventing welfare-negative ones seems most productive for short-term projects, but I am concerned that "good" PLF will enable something similar to corporate greenwashing, providing measures for animal welfare that are substituted for actual welfare in the same way that economic stats like GDP are often substituted for human (or animal!) welfare.  Unfortunately, for tractability, I do think regulatory oversight is much more realistic for now.

answers.question: One might think that it is more important to work towards the abolition of factory farming altogether, rather than trying to steer the development & regulation of PLF and its associated AI sensor technologies. Abolition versus welfarist development and regulatory oversight: what are the arguments for and against each? In a few short reasoned bullets or sentences write down which YOU think is the more impactful and tractable route to animal protection - and why? (Tip: try and think of at least two bullets from whatever your opposing point of view is)
answers.answer:
I think the abolition of factory farming will be more impactful, but the welfarist development and regulatory oversight will be more tractable.
I am not confident that humanity can turn vegetarian and/or vegan overnight, but I believe a gradual phase out of factory farming and/or animal rearing should begin immediately.
An overnight abolishment will cause great stress to the animals since they will have to either be relocated or slaughtered on a massive scale which might cause greater harm than good.
On the other hand, humanity might be stuck in the “transitionary phase” of phasing out factory farms, where the status quo of animal meat production remains.
I’d advocate for the abolition of factory farming because if the factory farms did not exist, the animal will not exist in the first place to cater to the needs of the consumers. The price of meat products will soar and meat, if available, is only accessible to a few people and only on some occasions.

answers.question: For discussion on tractability, see Brown (2024) & Simoneau-Gilbert & Birch (2024).
answers.answer:
Threat 6: End-User Spends Less (Quality) Time With Animals

Based on the threat elaboration on the paper, due to the prevalent use of Precision Livestock Farming, the end-user, or in this case, the farmers, will have less interactions with the animals that they rear. The farmers will only attend to the animals as and when is needed, usually when the PLF system flags an issue with the individual animal. So when the animals do interact with humans, the animals are not used to said interactions hence they might feel more distressed and upset.

In this case, through the application of PLF, it will affect the lives of millions, if not billions of farmed animals. I would say that the impact of PLF can either be positive as it can address the pain points of animals and giving more free time to farmers to tend to their animals, or it can be used to scale up operations to generate more profit using the same amount of workforce. If regulation is pushed to the masses before the application of PLF becomes an industry-wide standard, we could address possible threats such as the one currently discussed more efficiently and effectively, hence better control of how PLF is used throughout the farming industry.

answers.question: How to measure welfare?Critics worry that the metrics tracked by PLF may not actually correspond with the welfare of animals. How exactly welfare is defined & measured makes all the difference. What risks might there be if there is a “gap” between welfare & the proxy measures that are tracked by PLF?
answers.answer:
PLF might be used to promote “welfare-washing” products. Take meat products that are marketed and packaged with the “organically-produced” label, for example. Some may argue on how “organic” the product is. This might be the case for meat products produced in farms applying PLF technology. Just because a meat product is produced using PLF technology, it does not mean that the animals’ welfare is taken into account.

Besides that, if PLF does not accurately track welfare of animals, it could exacerbate harm to the animals. Due to the novelty of PLF, tracking systems of animals may not be very well-established. Hence to improve accuracy, the developers may resort to more intrusive ways of tracking animals that may involve probes or tags. This may in turn cause harm to the animal or alter their natural behaviour. The tracking device itself may even attract pests such as red mites when used in tracking chickens.

answers.question: One might think that it is more important to work towards the abolition of factory farming altogether, rather than trying to steer the development & regulation of PLF and its associated AI sensor technologies. Abolition versus welfarist development and regulatory oversight: what are the arguments for and against each? In a few short reasoned bullets or sentences write down which YOU think is the more impactful and tractable route to animal protection - and why? (Tip: try and think of at least two bullets from whatever your opposing point of view is)
answers.answer:
Yes, the movement's focus should be shutting down factory farming as part of a larger transition to a just food system. PLF could provide small welfare improvements to a small number of individuals. For example, if a cow is identified as being ill through PLF, perhaps she will be killed sooner than she would be otherwise and relieved of her suffering. But PLF will not improve the cow's original situation. The most PLF seems to offer farmed animals are mild improvements that coincidentally benefit producers' bottom lines (such as automated body sensors that are less intrusive than the alternative or trackers that allow animals to move greater distances).
And much more alarmingly, PLF will be used to dramatically increase the number of cows in her position, increasing the overall amount of suffering exponentially. There is no indication that the animal agriculture industry has any interest in providing even modest improvements for animals, as evidenced by the difficulty of banning cages in egg and pig production in the Global North.

answers.question: For discussion on tractability, see Brown (2024) & Simoneau-Gilbert & Birch (2024).
answers.answer:
Threat 8: Housing and Management Adapted to PLF Instead of Animals
Scale - Massive, will impact billions of farmed animals
Severity - Intense animal suffering, potential to change all open air/free-roaming systems to indoor cages
Tractability - Mixed, unlikely to be able to exert much pressure in US where tech oligarchs are very powerful, but that might mildly counter-balanced by successful (so far) political and corporate campaigns to ban the worst confinement systems for certain farmed animals

answers.question: How to measure welfare?Critics worry that the metrics tracked by PLF may not actually correspond with the welfare of animals. How exactly welfare is defined & measured makes all the difference. What risks might there be if there is a “gap” between welfare & the proxy measures that are tracked by PLF?
answers.answer: We measure welfare in farmed animals as a lack of a negative - the animal is uninjured and free from disease.  Alone, these are preferred states for animals to be in (as opposed to injured and sick). But when we prioritize these over positive welfare (ability to move and explore, ability to socialize), then we create a life full of suffering. PLF/AI will make it easier to monitor and profit from massive contained systems where animals are tightly controlled.

answers.question: One might think that it is more important to work towards the abolition of factory farming altogether, rather than trying to steer the development & regulation of PLF and its associated AI sensor technologies. Abolition versus welfarist development and regulatory oversight: what are the arguments for and against each? In a few short reasoned bullets or sentences write down which YOU think is the more impactful and tractable route to animal protection - and why? (Tip: try and think of at least two bullets from whatever your opposing point of view is)
answers.answer:
We can and shouldpush for better regulation and oversight of PLF while keeping abolition as our compass.
Focusing on PLF doesn’t mean we accept factory farming. It means we’re trying to reduce suffering where we can, while planting seeds for something better. Advocacy isn’t all-or-nothing. Sometimes, the most powerful change comes from meeting people where they are  and guiding them toward where we all need to go.

answers.question: For discussion on tractability, see Brown (2024) & Simoneau-Gilbert & Birch (2024).
answers.answer:
Risk: Reduced Human-Animal Interaction

As precision livestock technologies gain traction, there’s a growing risk that human-animal interaction will decrease.

Scale: This could become a widespread issue, especially as more farms start adopting PLF systems.

Severity: Moderate to high. Less interaction can dull empathy, make it harder to catch subtle signs of distress or illness, and even increase stress in animals who aren’t used to human contact.

Tractability: Moderately addressable. We can design systems that still require human checks and make sure farmers are trained not to rely on tech alone especially when it comes to welfare.

Uncertainties: What level of human interaction is actually necessary for good welfare? And over time, how might reduced contact shape animal behavior or well-being?

answers.question: How to measure welfare?Critics worry that the metrics tracked by PLF may not actually correspond with the welfare of animals. How exactly welfare is defined & measured makes all the difference. What risks might there be if there is a “gap” between welfare & the proxy measures that are tracked by PLF?
answers.answer: One of the main concerns with PLF is that it often checks things like how fast animals grow, how much they move, or their body temperature, instead of looking at how they feel or behave. If there’s a gap between what the system measures and what actually matters to the animals, we might think their lives are better than they really are. This could cause people to miss signs of stress, boredom, or suffering just because they are harder to track with machines. In the end, how we choose to measure animal welfare is not just a technical issue—it’s a moral one. If we only focus on what’s easy to measure, we might miss what truly matters to the animals themselves.

answers.question: One might think that it is more important to work towards the abolition of factory farming altogether, rather than trying to steer the development & regulation of PLF and its associated AI sensor technologies. Abolition versus welfarist development and regulatory oversight: what are the arguments for and against each? In a few short reasoned bullets or sentences write down which YOU think is the more impactful and tractable route to animal protection - and why? (Tip: try and think of at least two bullets from whatever your opposing point of view is)
answers.answer: eciding whether to focus on abolishing factory farming or shaping the future of Precision Livestock Farming (PLF) isn’t easy. Both paths are deeply important, and both affect the lives of billions of animals. On one hand, factory farming is the biggest source of animal suffering today. Animals live in confinement, subjected to cruelty for the sake of profit. We’re finally making progress, laws are shifting, plant-based options are rising, and public awareness is growing. Abandoning this effort now would feel like giving up just before a breakthrough, which would be bad given the resources and time spent. Morally, it’s clear: factory farming must end. But on the other hand, PLF, a high-tech, AI-driven system for managing animals, could be the future. And that’s exactly the concern. It might become a more advanced, more hidden version of factory farming, automated, data-driven, and harder to monitor. Yet, PLF isn’t inherently bad. It’s not limited to cruel systems. It can be used in more humane settings or even to monitor wild animal welfare. It’s a tool, and tools can be steered. The emotional conflict is real: urgency to stop suffering now vs. responsibility to prevent harm tomorrow. There’s fear of a worse system replacing the old, but also hope that we can shape it for good. Ultimately, the most impactful path may not be choosing one over the other, but connecting both. We can finish the fight against factory farming while influencing how PLF evolves. That way, we not only end current cruelty but also ensure we don’t create new forms of suffering in its place. Additionally, the challenge of PLF is similar to the question of whether a gun should have been invented or not, given the fact that it has the potential to end a life swiftly.

answers.answer: My background, skills and interests lead me to risk 4: Lack of uptake of the most meaningful indicators for animal welfare. Scale: High PLF systems are being deployed across industries that handle billions of animals, especially poultry, pigs, and dairy. However, most current tools monitor productivity, not welfare (e.g. pain or stress). As a result, vast numbers of animals may suffer unseen and unaddressed, making the scale of risk enormous. Severity: High The absence of meaningful indicators (like distress calls or injury detection) means animals can endure chronic suffering in highly automated environments. This creates a false impression of welfare and makes cruelty harder to detect or prove. The impact on animal lives is , deep and long-term. Tractability: Moderate to High Technologically, better indicators are possible, like using AI for behavioural cues or stress biomarkers. Practically, adoption is slowed by cost concerns, industry priorities, and weak regulations. Still, animal welfare advocates, scientists, and policymakers can shape the direction PLF takes with targeted pressure. key uncertainties. 1. Definition Uncertainty: There's no clear consensus on what counts as a "meaningful" welfare indicator, should it focus only on suffering, or also include positive welfare? 2. Data Availability: PLF tools are often proprietary, so it's unclear what welfare data is actually being collected or used. 3. Adoption vs. Potential: Even if welfare indicators exist, it’s uncertain whether farms will adopt them over cheaper, productivity-focused metrics. 4. Ethical & Political Influence: It’s unclear who will shape PLF’s future, industry, regulators, or advocates, making its ethical direction unpredictable.

answers.question: How to measure welfare?Critics worry that the metrics tracked by PLF may not actually correspond with the welfare of animals. How exactly welfare is defined & measured makes all the difference. What risks might there be if there is a “gap” between welfare & the proxy measures that are tracked by PLF?
answers.answer: For chickens, issues like lameness, overcrowding, and cannibalism may go unaddressed if systems focus only on growth. Bone deformities and heart failure may arise due to breeding pressures. In pigs, tail biting, stress, pain from mutilations, and stereotypic behaviours could persist undetected without proper social or pain metrics. For cattle, welfare risks like lameness, mastitis, calf-mother separation, and zero-grazing distress may remain invisible if only milk yield or weight is tracked. Other species like ducks, turkeys, goats, and sheep face being excluded from PLF design, making their unique welfare needs (e.g., water access for ducks, pain from tail docking in sheep) overlooked. Across all species, AI systems might automate cruelty, give a false sense of welfare, and cause ethical washing, appearing humane while animals suffer silently. How AI might exacerbate such 'suffering risks'? AI in Precision Livestock Farming (PLF) can worsen animal suffering by optimising productivity over welfare, hiding distress behind “green” dashboards, and scaling harm rapidly. Poorly designed systems may miss pain, fear, or stress, especially in underrepresented species. Data gaps, biased training, and reduced human oversight further risk silent suffering. AI can also be used for “welfare-washing,” masking cruelty as innovation. Without ethical safeguards, AI may automate and entrench widespread suffering. How might we reduce them? Reducing AI-driven suffering in PLF means designing systems around real animal welfare, not just productivity. Key steps include using species-specific welfare indicators, ensuring transparency, building ethical failsafes, improving training data, supporting human oversight, aligning policy incentives, and involving animal advocates in tech design.

(Tip: try and think of at least two bullets from whatever your opposing point of view is)
answers.answer:
Abolition:
- AI implementation will be used for increasing the production of factory farms, hence will increase the scale of their presence through lowering the prices of animal products.
- Out-competing smaller farmers with potentially greater concerns for animal welfare
- AI will be needed mostly in big factory farms where unnaturally high stocking density of animals will result in greater epidemiological risk and illness transfer with the premise of improving the ethical dimension of the harmful system. Hence it will primarily be used to brand harmful means and conditions of production more positively.
- AI implementation does not increase the amount of space per individual, does not reduce the number of cruel practices like beak or tail culling, nor does it allow for the animals to bond with each other
Welfarist development:
- The benefit of lowering the abuse from hands of farmers, reducing the advanced epidemiological outbreaks, hence potentially improving the quality of life of animals suffering from illness and slightly reducing the epidemiological risk coming with factory farms to humans, wild and companion animals
- With greater surveillance comes greater possibility of control form the public, NGO’s and governments

At the end of the day, even working toward a highly regulated factory farming scenario where animals are treated humanely, with their welfare in mind, will be because the welfare affects their value in a positive manner in terms of their use for the farmer/ system itself, and if the ultimate goal is to not have hierarchies in the value of any life, then it cannot be to capitalize on another creature's existence. answers.answer: Risk 12: Promotion of animal consumption and Harm Scale: The extent to which adoption of PLF drives up the volume, affordability, and consumption of animal products would be global. The distribution would be skewed toward existing larger players with the means for early investment, and lobbying for regulation support. Severity: The risks would potentially be the same as the current system which prioritizes profit for an overpopulated, consumption driven society, with just an illusion of "humane" treatment. Tractability: Low - medium: The regulation would have to clearly define what harm looks like- who decides? who enforces? And who benefits? are key questions, all of which point to many differing voices in this space. For current players in the factory farming market a bare minimum of "welfare" might be a worthwhile tradeoff, if it means scaling up and profiting, potentially providing them with more power, to grow and influence regulation as well. If the case is that farming is ethical, but conditions of factory farming aren't, then production of "ethically sourced" meat will only go up. Uncertainties: -Innovation in lab grown meats could be a viable substitute , and could change the industry as we know it. -Increased data via PLF could support collection of a lot of data which could also support study in fields that could support a stronger case for empathy

As someone who wants to end animal farming, I also know we’re not there yet. So in my opinion we need both approaches:

• In the short term, we need to push for real improvements that reduce animal suffering, especially in the worst systems. Support tools and rules that actually make life better for animals, but keep an eye on how they’re used.

• In the long term, we need to keep building support for ending animal farming altogether. Use those welfare wins to start conversations about why animals are farmed in the first place, and whether that’s something we should keep doing at all.

answers.answer:
I chose 'Speciesism': emphasising technological management may reinforce the notion of animals as mere production units, diminishing their moral consideration.

• Scale – Very widespread.

Our whole farming system already treats animals as objects. PLF risks making this worse by turning animals into data points, especially in big factory farms with millions of animals.

• Severity – Pretty serious.

If animals are seen as machines, not living beings, it's easier to ignore their suffering. Even if PLF helps in some ways, it could actually make factory farming seem more acceptable, just because it's “smart” or “efficient.”

• Tractability – Yes we can do something about it, but it’s not easy. We can push for:

- Tech that respects animals as individuals
- Public awareness about what PLF really does
- Ethical standards that don’t just boost productivity

pro:

Threat 9: Facilitation of intensive systems

This threat seems large in scale since I'd expect all factory farms with PLF systems to increase productivity by increasing the number of farmed animals which could be made feasible by the advanced monitoring systems

I'm more uncertain about the severity but I'd guess that the increased density would cause negative experiences in animals that may not be visible physically. For example, increased stress and inability to behave in natural ways.

Threat 4: Focus on the Measurable Rather Than Meaningful

The scale of this problem could become extensive if implemented in major livestock farms. With the consolidation of livestock farming operations, the majority are raised in large factory farms which could implement PLF and has the potential to over-index on what can be measured rather than what is actually valuable for an animal.

Depending on how it is implemented the severity could differ. If farmers simply game the measuring system it's possible that the animals could live in even worse conditions than they currently do even though the metrics say the opposite.

answers.question: One might think that it is more important to work towards the abolition of factory farming altogether, rather than trying to steer the development & regulation of PLF and its associated AI sensor technologies. Abolition versus welfarist development and regulatory oversight: what are the arguments for and against each? In a few short reasoned bullets or sentences write down which YOU think is the more impactful and tractable route to animal protection - and why? (Tip: try and think of at least two bullets from whatever your opposing point of view is)
answers.answer:
Arguments for abolition:
- Animal ag companies will only use PLF if it's financially beneficial to them, so any short-term welfare improvements will come at the cost of propping the industry up financially for years or decades longer than it might otherwise survive
- Factory farming is fundamentally exploitative and unethical and incremental changes will never make it a system to be proud of
- AI will only further remove people from the reality of factory farming through widespread automation
- PLF brings huge risks as a tool for animal ag companies' humane-washing toolbox

Arguments for PLF:
- We have a chance to prevent significant suffering for a vast number of animals. In many cases animals' and producers' interests are aligned, e.g. preventing disease and injury and mortalities.
- Factory farming isn't going to disappear overnight. While we work towards abolition we need to focus on making it as close to ethical as possible in the meantime.
- Governments and the public are becoming more compassionate towards animals so society will probably ensure that PLF is only used in their interests, not solely for corporate profit.
- PLF gives us an unprecedented opportunity to closely monitor huge numbers of animals and analyse the data to understand more about their subjective experiences and how to allow them to lead good lives.

My view:
- PLF will never make factory farming an acceptable part of society and corporate interests will typically trump animals' interests, just as they have in every other facet of factory farming. But like it or not, AI will shape factory farming this century, and we should do our best to harness it for the good of animals while also fighting to end factory farming altogether.

answers.answer: Threat 11: Increased Animal Instrumentalization Scale: 9; Severity: 8; Tractability: 5 Scenario: I'm focussing on autonomous farms as an extreme (but still realistic) form of this Examples: -- Better Origin farming insects in enclosed shipping containers -- Industry players talking on podcasts about fully autonomous fish farms being the 'North Star' of the industry -- Atarraya's Shrimpbox Farms 'the first AI-powered, hyper-modular aquaculture farm designed to allow the production of the freshest and most sustainable shrimp. We enable local shrimp to be grown anywhere in the world, even in urban and colder climates' -- Vertical Oceans’ autonomous shrimp farms - ‘a fully autonomous, fully self-contained, multitrophic system’. It's telling that they mention that their systems are used to 'grow' shrimps and sea grapes, as if shrimps are also just a plant. -- ReelData and Farm in a Box partnership: 'a modular, prefabricated, “next-generation system” in land-based aquaculture. So far autonomous farming has been very focussed on insects, fishes, and shrimps - this makes sense given they are way smaller so easier to pack into a pre-fabricated system, supposedly have less complex welfare needs, and aren't as likely to arouse public sympathy. Unfortunately they're also the animals that we farm in the highest numbers and whose welfare needs we least understand. There are some signs that this could start being used for other animals too; e.g. China's semi-automated 'pork skyscrapers', project proposals for almost entirely automated chicken farms, and Vertical Oceans' stated belief that their aquaculture tech could also be applied to chickens and cows. This seems like this will all add to the general tendency of animal farming being an invisible process where we get to enjoy the product without having to be confronted with how it was produced. The industry spiel around these systems is all about efficiency and sustainability, nothing about the welfare of the animals.

answers.question: How to measure welfare?Critics worry that the metrics tracked by PLF may not actually correspond with the welfare of animals. How exactly welfare is defined & measured makes all the difference. What risks might there be if there is a “gap” between welfare & the proxy measures that are tracked by PLF?
answers.answer: Farmers tend to conflate welfare and productivity. By their logic, animals need to be healthy in order to be productive, and if they're healthy that means they have good welfare. AI models designed to prioritize productivity over all else could be incredibly damaging as it would mean e.g. a) increasing stocking densities, b) increasing the 'yield' per animal, and c) being prepared to adopt approaches that harm or neglect many individuals in pursuit of increasing the productivity of the overall flock. Similarly, AI models designed to prioritize health could seriously jeopardize animal welfare. This already happens: producers justify keeping animals in indoor caged systems because there's a lower chance of disease spread. The same goes for physical injury; producers justify keeping animals in indoor caged systems because there's a lower chance of them injuring themselves. While health and physical injury have to factor into a model of welfare, they can't be used as justifications to cage animals at the expense of their psychological wellbeing. Also if AI models are trained to measure good/bad welfare solely on the basis of physical indicators like heart rate, this risks completely misdiagnosing the situation; an animal might have a high heart rate because they're excited or because they're afraid. Models need to be nuanced enough to recognise the difference. You can also imagine mortality being used as a proxy for good welfare, with farms having to achieve less than 1% mortality rate in order to be diagnosed 'high-welfare'. This would be a huge s-risk if it meant that AI models prioritized keeping horribly sick or injured animals alive when the more ethical approach would be to euthanize them. We need a much better understanding of animal welfare science for us to understand what good welfare looks like for different animals. This will vary from animal to animal and over the animal's life; e.g. young chickens have very different preferences to older chickens. AI can help us build this understanding by monitoring animals' behaviour and physiological state in many different situations, and monitoring their preferences based on what they eat, where they like to sleep, nest, forage, etc. But this needs to be coupled with human understanding and common sense.

answers.question: One might think that it is more important to work towards the abolition of factory farming altogether, rather than trying to steer the development & regulation of PLF and its associated AI sensor technologies. In a few short reasoned bullets or sentences write down which YOU think is the more impactful and tractable route to animal protection - and why? (Tip: try and think of at least two bullets from whatever your opposing point of view is)
answers.answer: While the abolition of factory farming aims to eliminate animal suffering entirely, it faces significant challenges due to entrenched economic interests, cultural practices, and political resistance. Conversely, implementing and regulating PLF technologies offers a more immediate opportunity to improve animal welfare within existing systems. PLF can enhance monitoring of individual animals, allowing for timely interventions to alleviate suffering. However, without proper oversight, PLF may exacerbate issues by further industrializing animal agriculture and reducing human-animal interactions. Given the current landscape, pursuing regulatory oversight of PLF technologies appears to be a more impactful and tractable route to improving animal welfare in the near term.

answers.answer:
Risk 5: Over-Reliance on PLF Technology
•	Scale: This risk potentially affects millions of animals globally, as PLF technologies are increasingly adopted in livestock farming.
•	Severity: High. Over-reliance on PLF can lead to diminished human oversight, resulting in missed welfare issues that automated systems fail to detect, thereby compromising animal well-being.
•	Tractability: Moderate. Addressing this risk requires comprehensive training for farmers to use PLF as a supplement rather than a replacement for human observation. Policies promoting balanced integration of technology and human care are essential.
Uncertainties: The extent to which farmers can maintain traditional husbandry skills alongside PLF usage remains unclear. Further research is needed to develop best practices for integrating PLF without diminishing human-animal relationships.

answers.question: How to measure welfare?Critics worry that the metrics tracked by PLF may not actually correspond with the welfare of animals. How exactly welfare is defined & measured makes all the difference. What risks might there be if there is a “gap” between welfare & the proxy measures that are tracked by PLF?
answers.answer: PLF systems often rely on proxy measures—such as activity levels, feed intake, or vocalizations—to assess animal welfare. If these proxies do not accurately reflect the animals' physical and psychological states, welfare issues may go unnoticed. For instance, an animal might appear physically healthy but suffer from stress or boredom, conditions not easily detected by current PLF metrics. This gap can lead to a false sense of security regarding animal well-being and may result in inadequate care. To mitigate this risk, it's crucial to develop more comprehensive welfare indicators that encompass both physical health and emotional states, ensuring that PLF technologies truly enhance animal welfare.

Abolition: 
- For: While PLF might seem to improve animal welfare, it is more effective in large-scale, caged, factory farming settings, signalling a possible return to this form of keeping farmed animals, thus actually increasing harm in the long-term.
- For: There can not be animal welfare in a system based on exploitation and certain death.

Threat 9: Facilitation of Intensive Systems
Scale: Very large as PLF works more effectively in intensive farming systems and these are known to house animals in inhumane, species-inadequate conditions
Severity: Moving back to caged and/or indoor farming systems to increase profitability will have a severe impact of the animals in question
Tractability: There might be some pushback against returning to cages and/or indoor systems, however it is possible that these ideals will be neglected upon availability to cheaper pricing

How exactly welfare is defined & measured makes all the difference. What risks might there be if there is a “gap” between welfare & the proxy measures that are tracked by PLF?
answers.answer: The picture of animal welfare is painted depending on how one defines animal welfare (either achieving positive experiences and/or avoiding negative ones) and the proxy measures that are chosen to define it.  The risks that come from this difference are manifold, but the most striking one is that fact that the animals in question might be deeply suffering and sick, but healthy according to the PLF measures selected for. Because manufacturers privilege profit over care and equality, they will push to commercialize products that farmers, also motivated by profit and efficiency, will buy, which are typically the avoidance of negative health states.

answers.question: One might think that it is more important to work towards the abolition of factory farming altogether, rather than trying to steer the development & regulation of PLF and its associated AI sensor technologies. Abolition versus welfarist development and regulatory oversight: what are the arguments for and against each? In a few short reasoned bullets or sentences write down which YOU think is the more impactful and tractable route to animal protection - and why? (Tip: try and think of at least two bullets from whatever your opposing point of view is)
answers.answer:
I lean toward the welfarist perspective; primarily out of pragmatism rather than conviction. Ideally, I would advocate for abolition. But realistically, global veganism is unlikely within this century. Raising awareness takes time, and in the meantime, the most tractable and impactful path is to focus on reducing suffering.

By steering the development of robust regulations and oversight mechanisms, Precision Livestock Farming (PLF) could meaningfully improve the lives of farmed animals. AI technologies may help (i) detect problems earlier than farmers or veterinarians, (ii) monitor thousands of animals individually: tracking sound, behavior, temperature, growth, injuries, parasites, and more, and (iii) become even more effective than humans through ongoing machine learning and feedback loops.

Counterarguments include:
•	Profit will likely always outweigh welfare in industrial systems; thus, PLF may never truly serve animals’ interests.
•	Meaningful change often requires radical, not incremental, reform.
•	As researcher Walter Veit argues, a good life is one in which positive experiences outweigh negative ones. But is this a fair definition for animals raised to be exploited and killed? Shouldn't the good life be one that the animal lives for itself—not for humankind? It should reflect the Greatest Happiness Principle, not the Least Suffering principle.
•	Virginie Sommeaux-Gilbert and Jonathan Birch warn against a dystopia where AI deepens the disconnection between humans and animals: “What are these animals? Your animals? It’s not important.”

These are serious concerns that give real weight to abolitionist arguments.

answers.question: For discussion on tractability, see Brown (2024) & Simoneau-Gilbert & Birch (2024).
answers.answer:
I chose to focus on the risk of indirect harm through the potential transformation of animal farming systems, particularly the shift in housing and management practices driven by adaptation to PLF technologies rather than to the animals themselves. This transformation could lead to higher stocking densities and increasingly artificial environments, thereby reducing overall welfare.
Scale: the potential impact is vast: an estimated 31 billion farmed vertebrate animals were alive globally in 2019 (Sentience Institute). Any systemic change in farming norms would therefore affect billions of individuals annually.
Severity: the severity depends on whether housing adaptations prioritize animal welfare. If small-scale, animal-centered approaches are preserved or mandated, negative impacts may be mitigated. Without such safeguards, however, animals could face intensified confinement and diminished agency.
Tractability: this risk is tractable. Policy interventions, updated animal welfare codes, and regulatory frameworks could be developed to ensure that housing transformations are designed around animal needs rather than solely for technological efficiency.

answers.question: How to measure welfare?Critics worry that the metrics tracked by PLF may not actually correspond with the welfare of animals. How exactly welfare is defined & measured makes all the difference. What risks might there be if there is a “gap” between welfare & the proxy measures that are tracked by PLF?
answers.answer:
As researchers have noted, “What can be measured by PLF systems is not necessarily what is most meaningful to measure for animal welfare” (Tuyttens et al., 2023). Current technologies tend to focus on identifying welfare problems, like limiting suffering or detecting disease outbreaks, rather than promoting positive welfare states, such as pleasure or contentment.

This creates a serious risk of welfare being reduced to what is easily quantifiable. For instance, an animal confined in a high-density cage might show no physiological distress (normal temperature, heart rate, etc.), yet still experience emotional suffering due to lack of space or stimulation; conditions the sensors might overlook. If there is a gap between actual welfare and the proxy measures tracked by PLF, animals could appear “fine” by technical standards while enduring prolonged and unrecognized suffering.

Proponents of AI in PLF suggest that these systems could one day track individual welfare. But for now, they tend to generalize for efficiency, potentially missing outliers or subtle signs of distress. To mitigate this, it’s vital to involve experienced human caretakers and ensure that independent, holistic welfare assessments remain part of the process.

(Tip: try and think of at least two bullets from whatever your opposing point of view is)
answers.answer:
In support of welfarist development, let's consider PLF and its capacity to improve animal welfare, in general. Whether it's a factory-farming scenario or large animal sanctuary operations (one for animal slaughter and the other for animal protection and long-term care) PLF tech can significantly improve the welfare and experiences of animals in both scenarios. PLF can measure negative animal experiences (measure stress, distress, frustration, sickness, etc.) and positive experiences and make important decisions. Whether or not factory farming is abolished, focusing on tech to improve animal experiences can benefit large scale and small scale animal operations.

Contrarily, the case that factory farming should be abolished is that PLF may prolong and encourage more crueler forms of factory farming. In addition to the risk that operations could be maximized for PLF and efficient productivity and less for animal welfare, other risks associated with including PLF in factory farming include: more invasive sensors and devices, potentially adding to discomfort and distress and possibility of tech failure; failure to capture or properly assess distress behaviors for wide spread animals; significant failures could be catastrophically overlooked from the reliance leading to undetected suffering for animals (even consumers).

answers.answer:
Threat 6 --> End-User Spends Less (Quality) Time With Animals --> hypothesis: "the amount of interaction and care for living beings positively affects our concern for them and our attitude toward them." The author includes that there is a potential for "increase in the amount of fear and stress experienced by the animals when handling is performed," and possible "negative spiral in which farmer's job satisfaction is reduced and could in turn further worsen how the farmer interacts with the animals," including reduction of the farmer's knowledge of the individuals in the herd.

Scale: Depending on the size of the farming operation this would be significant. Imagine 2030 PLF being adopted by 75% of farms.

Severity: I believe the impact of this will be quite severe, especially because I already have the belief that farmers care so little for the well-being of the animals they forcibly breed, tear away from their mothers, regularly stun, and murder.

Tractability: I think there is tremendous potential for humans to change/impact this. What may reduce it is the costs and time farmers are willing to devote. Imagine have a team whose role it is to follow-up PLF measures with routine daily positive regard and care; farmers would have to be willing to budget in an expense like this.

How exactly welfare is defined & measured makes all the difference. What risks might there be if there is a “gap” between welfare & the proxy measures that are tracked by PLF?
answers.answer: Tuyttens' includes in his "Threat 3: Poor External Validation of the PLF System" the possibility for PLF systems to inaccurately monitor conditions as well as "perform poorly under real-life conditions, possibly resulting in unreliable alerts, with both false positives and false negatives." The risk is that this could impact the qualities of the animals' lives and the human-animal relationship, with discomfort (physical for the animal) and frustration (mental for the human caretaker). Some variables that could impact this include, how good or accurate the training data is (garbage in, garbage out) and the capacity for human biases to train AI.

In a few short reasoned bullets or sentences write down which YOU think is the more impactful and tractable route to animal protection - and why? (Tip: try and think of at least two bullets from whatever your opposing point of view is)
answers.answer:
Abolishing factory farming would be ideal, but it would take a general revolution and worldwide disruption. The author who said the AI genie is out of the bottle is correct- one can't use a computer or an app without AI options. Working to make adoption of truly ethical systems (rather than PR ethics, as the articles described) is the more practical approach. However, if there is a general revolution and a true 'eat the rich' moment, changing how everything is done would be in reach.  
Abolition:
For: 1. Except for worldwide veganism, it could lead to the best life for food animals. 2. It would lead to more people being close to their food sources and probably less meat-eating. 
Against: 1. It would lead to increased meat costs, and perhaps a less well-fed population in some places. 2. It would take a massive cultural shift to stop the capitalist machine that dictates the need for factory farming. 
Welfarist development: 
For: We can train AI to be more ethical and welfare oriented than farmers. 2. AI can be faster to see problems with individual animals. 
Against: Bad actors will use AI to increase profit and dial down welfare. 2. Decreasing the connection between humans and people can lead to some people being less ethical or caring toward animals.

answers.answer:
All 12 threats were reasonable, but I will focus on the first, as it genuinely worries me. Currently, generative AI has frequent systemic errors that slow chat AI or reasoning errors, like the inability to remember what day it is. Combined with power outages and weather-related problems, AI-powered PLF could be a nightmare of disasters. 
It is a large-scale problem as factory farming has become the norm worldwide. If half of those operations used PLF, and the same type of problems affected systems that control feeding or animal welfare, it could lead to large-scale suffering. AI cannot reason well enough currently to be in charge of living animals. We see this in different business simulations where AI threatens bodily harm to another AI business if they don't comply, or that AI changes the rules of the simulation to be successful. If AI were programmed for financial gain only, it could lead to dystopian animal welfare scenarios. The suffering of factory farms is already so great; adding the worry that AI could mistake a cow for a threat, or stop feeding animals mistakenly, is horrifying. Currently, the possibility of basic mechanical failures from power outages or weather disasters already affects factory farms, increasing the severity of possible suffering.  

As for tractability, I think right now, as AI is becoming commonplace, is the time to get ahead of the problem. We can't let 'big ag' be the ones to set the bar on suffering or AI ethics. I also don't believe people who are simply in the computer/AI space should be the ones who set the rules. It needs to be people from many walks of life- business, underserved communities, animal welfare, and farmers from small and large farms that work together to make the rules and hopefully laws.

answers.question: How to measure welfare?Critics worry that the metrics tracked by PLF may not actually correspond with the welfare of animals. How exactly welfare is defined & measured makes all the difference. What risks might there be if there is a “gap” between welfare & the proxy measures that are tracked by PLF?
answers.answer: The gap is between true welfare and metrics that might look good. For example, a pig could gain weight but be miserable in a small crate.  It's similar to how chickens can be called 'free range' if they have access to some outdoors, although they still live in horrible conditions. One of the articles mentioned "tech-washing"- where the metrics of the animals look good, but they don't have true welfare, the ability to behave naturally. Consumers might buy the animal products, assuming the metrics meant that the animals were treated ethically and humanely. Once the general public finds out, it could lead to a backlash, somewhat like the recycling backlash, where some people feel all waste, recyclable or not, ends up in the trash, so there is no use in recycling.  If PLF systems are used to incentivize animal growth, it could lead to less humane treatment by systems prioritizing growth and suffering.

I do think the risk of their failure (in many ways) is so high that it is worth requiring certain back up plans and manual abilities.

answers.answer:
Threat 1: Technical failures
The scale of an event can be large, an entire farm, unit, or even region could be effected by storm, fire, flood or malfunction causing widespread power outage that would effect the system. If the farm is too reliant on the mechanized system for animal care, the animals will suffer and the potential severity is very high. Tractability for basic safety features and plans for failure seems essential and a way to develop such protocols and safeguards in parallel with ones needed for systems upon which humans may become overly dependent. 
System failure is never an "if" but always a "when".

answers.answer: If there is a gap between true welfare and the proxy measures tracked by the PLF, the system will be maximizing the wrong value. It is like a teacher having the kids memorize the answers rather than actually learning. The system perpetuates it's own misunderstanding, optimizing further the thing it is tracking that has no bearing on actual animal welfare. The risks associated with this include self- congratulatory marketing claims that numb people to actual reality and develop a false sense of moral exoneration. Another risk is a missed opportunity to measure and improve real welfare and QOL.

answers.answer: I do not believe that abolition is more strategic, given the scale of the industry, the length of time it takes to change behaviour, and the weight of financial interests. I believe that finding ways to improve and provide alternatives to animal protein consumption may be more strategic and generate long-term change, creating a better environment for more ambitious changes. Well planed and pushing for a stronger focus on positive animal emotions, PLF could play a positive role.

answers.answer: Reduced Quality Time with Animals: PLF aims to reduce labor, but this freed-up time may be used to increase herd size rather than spending more quality time with animals. This can lead to animals becoming less habituated to humans and a reduction in human attention to individuals, potentially increasing fear during handling and reducing the farmer's ability to detect subtle problems. This also risks objectifying animals, as less interaction may reduce empathy. In terms of scale: this could affect the lives of millions of animals kept in intensive systems, and drive an increase in the number of animals. In terms of severity: the disconnection of animals as sentient beings from the owners/workers could worsen the already poor relationship some people have with animals. Traceability: disconnection with the animals as sentient beings don't necessarily affect the traceability, although the ¨mechanization¨ of these procedures could potentially reduce the interest of people/consumers in understanding what is going on with the animals or where they come from. Using the PLF system on a careful way with genuine interest for the animals, or under the right legal framework, this could result in positive impacts for scale, reducing severity of welfare issues, or improving traceability.

How exactly welfare is defined & measured makes all the difference. What risks might there be if there is a “gap” between welfare & the proxy measures that are tracked by PLF?
answers.answer: A significant risk in PLF is the potential for a "proxy failure," where the measurable indicators tracked by AI systems do not accurately or comprehensively reflect the true welfare of the animals. This "gap" can lead to several threats like focusing on the measurable over the meaningful, where PLF systems would primarily focus on production efficiency and farmer quality of life, rather than animal welfare. This means what can be measured by PLF may not be what is most meaningful for animal welfare.

But I do think the abolition of factory farming should be getting most resources. This is because it has a lot higher impact then the impact focus. The abolition or large scale industrial farms would be good for animals, people, and the environment. While welfarist development and regulatory oversight can still be bad for all three. In a few short reasoned bullets or sentences write down which YOU think is the more impactful and tractable route to animal protection - and why? (Tip: try and think of at least two bullets from whatever your opposing point of view is)
answers.answer:
Points in favor of abolition:
- PLF could lead to additional problems in intensive farms, as discussed in the readings (increased speciesism, fine tuning parameters in detrimental ways, over-reliance on these systems, etc).
- It is simply not just to be factory farming animals, whether or not we slightly improve their conditions.
Points in favor of regulation and PLF:
- Realistically, people are not going to give up factory farming (at least not for a long time). It is better to increase the welfare of the animals in farms than to fight an uphill, impossible battle.
- PLF would increase efficiency, possibly improving welfare for animals while also reducing the cost of (non-vegan) food. 

I am not sure which side I believe in more. It is a nuanced question with a nuanced answer. Certainly there are elements of both sides that I agree with.

answers.answer:
I chose threat 1: Technical Failures Within the PLF System.
Scale - Depends on the specific instances, but potentially billions of animals. 
Severity - Animals' needs could be neglected, leading to starvation, dehydration, and/or lack of awareness of diseases/injuries in farms.
Tractability - extremely tractable, given that the tractability depends on humans noticing the technical failures. Once noticed, it is easy to document what happened and how many animals were affected.

How exactly welfare is defined & measured makes all the difference. What risks might there be if there is a “gap” between welfare & the proxy measures that are tracked by PLF?
answers.answer: Welfare is defined as the balance of positive and negative experiences of an animal. If there is a gap between how welfare is measured and what it actually is, this could have detrimental effects. For example, if dehydration measurement proxies are inaccurate for female livestock, this could lead to the death/suffering of all female animals in a farm (or many farms). There are countless other ways that this could cause harm, but the bottom line is that a mismatch in measurement proxies and reality could be extremely harmful.

answers.question: One might think that it is more important to work towards the abolition of factory farming altogether, rather than trying to steer the development & regulation of PLF and its associated AI sensor technologies. Abolition versus welfarist development and regulatory oversight: what are the arguments for and against each? In a few short reasoned bullets or sentences write down which YOU think is the more impactful and tractable route to animal protection - and why? (Tip: try and think of at least two bullets from whatever your opposing point of view is)
answers.answer:
If we're looking at pure numbers, improvements to animal welfare/protection brought on AI-powered PLF can almost be near immediate, while campaigning and lobbying for policy change, funding valid and effective studies for alternative proteins, lab-grown meat, etc, and scaling these developments/technologies to a feasible level with take a few decades, and even then with no guarantee that they will be accepted or sustainable. So if we're prioritising quantitative measures, aka cold hard numbers alone, I am forced to argue for practical reasons that we should support and fund research into PLF applications and have them rolled out--yesterday! But what does welfare and protection actually mean if at the end of the day, these happy animals are condemned to be killed and eaten. Why bother sharing the fact and acknowledging heart-warming truths such as cows having best friends, if we can quickly and conveniently forget that knowledge when ordering a steak? Why does the concept of welfare and protection not include the preservation of life--why stop at minimising pain and suffering? 

The question of which perspective/approach is better presumes a false equivalence in their goals: abolitionists are not concerned just with improving metrics of animal welfare and suffering but also intangible, epistemic concerns re: our non-human animal and animal relationship: why do we enact the presumed right to eat animals (some over others), especially when there is indisputable facts that the animals we eat are sentient and capable of experiencing deep emotions and pain? Why are we not throwing billions at alt. protein research and lab-grown meat, which will enable us to still enjoy meat but without the suffering?

answers.answer:
Threat 4: Focus on the Measurable Rather Than Meaningful

Scale: Very high
Severity: Very high
Tractibility: Very high

No technology is perfect as human decision-making, and thus the factors/metrics to look for when improving animal welfare, can be highly flawed, specific, and exclusive. These systems would be implemented on a large number of animals (perhaps not a lot of different species), so the impact would affect millions. The severity would also be very high as mistakes/flaws can lead to a more, or even a more complex (e.g., psychological harm) kind of harm to the animals. There is still a lot of opportunity for testing that can be done to ensure that these risks can be addressed early, during, and after their implementation, and can be readily removed if they are not achieving their intended effect.

Based on the provided resources, there are several arguments both for and against Precision Livestock Farming (PLF), particularly within the context of welfarist development and regulatory oversight. While I won’t delve into those details, it is important to note that abolition theory remains the ideal goal we are striving toward.

Arguments in Favor of Abolition:
1. Ending factory farming would liberate animals from commodification, exploitation, and systematic abuse, both physically and emotionally. No sentient being should endure mass suffering when it is avoidable.
2.Abolition could serve as a catalyst for dismantling broader social injustices beyond the realm of animal welfare.
3.It would significantly curb environmental degradation and reduce migrant labor exploitation, addressing critical humanitarian and ecological concerns.

Arguments Against Abolition:

1. Abolition, like Marxist theories, may seem utopian and unrealistic given the current economic landscape. While welfarists ultimately share the goal of abolition, they advocate for a gradual transition, emphasizing improved welfare measures and regulations along the way.
2. There is a stark lack of regional and local outreach within the current Effective Altruism (EA) and vegan movements. Most research, campaigns, and policy initiatives disproportionately focus on privileged, high-income societies. Until these disparities are addressed, the shift toward total abolition will remain unattainable.

2. This threat is significant on scale & severity because we have enough data points to prove that working at farms and spending quality time with animals have contributed to vegan conversion with examples such as slaughterhouse workers becoming vegan activists.

1. Escalation of animal suffering and exploitation, mass breeding and industrialized handling of sentient beings inflicting physical and emotional distress, reinforcing the cycle of suffering.
2. Lack of welfare metrics fuels expansion of factory farming. Inadequate/bad welfare metrics will enable industries to prioritize profit over humane treatment, leading to the incorporation of more animals into factory farming. Species that were previously farmed under less intensive methods or not farmed at all, may be subjected to mechanized and large-scale operations, further worsening conditions.
3. we can see long-term worsening of socioeconomic and environmental consequences. In the short term, the declining prices of meat and animal products may help lower- and middle-class consumers manage inflation. But over time, however, factory farming expansion could worsen wealth inequality as corporations monopolize farmland and displace indigenous communities, destroying both habitats and livelihoods. It will reduce human labor, leading to potential wage suppression and job losses in agricultural sectors dependent on factory farming practices.

The problem is that for it to develop this knowledge, it might make irreversible mistakes on unsuspecting, innocent animals in the meantime.

I believe regulating and improving Precision Livestock Farming (PLF) is currently the more impactful and tractable route to animal protection, though not ideal.

Arguments for PLF focused regulation (my position):
Realistic short-term impact: Factory farming is entrenched globally; abolishing it soon is politically and economically implausible. Improving conditions via PLF can reduce suffering for billions of animals now.
Leverage over industry trends: PLF adoption is accelerating. Shaping its development ethically before it's fully locked in may prevent large-scale harm and institutionalized neglect.

Arguments for abolition (opposing view):
Moral clarity: Abolitionism sends a clear message that using sentient beings as production units is wrong, instead of merely managing their suffering.
Avoids technological lock-in: Investing in PLF may entrench factory farming further, making future abolition politically harder and economically more costly.

Why I choose PLF oversight:
Because perfect justice is often unattainable, and real improvements in how animals are treated can be achieved now by regulating AI applications, ensuring transparency, and enforcing welfare action when problems are detected.

Threat 9: PLF Facilitates Further Intensification of Animal Farming
1. Scale - High
Affects billions of animals globally, especially poultry and pigs. As PLF tools scale, even low-welfare systems can become more economically viable. Risk is global, particularly acute in countries with weak regulation (e.g., US, China, Brazil).
2. Severity - Very High
Intensification often leads to: Higher stocking densities, Reduced individual care, Increased disease and mortality rates, PLF may mask these harms behind productivity metrics (e.g. AI reports stable temperature while ignoring psychological suffering). May entrench factory farming further and displace higher-welfare systems.
3. Tractability - Moderate to Low
According to Brown (2024): structural industry incentives are hard to shift; economic logic favors scalable, efficient systems even if welfare is poor. As Simoneau-Gilbert & Birch (2024) argue, ethical oversight lags behind technical deployment, and current welfare laws often lack enforcement teeth. However, targeted interventions could help, e.g.: Regulatory limits on stocking density regardless of automation, Transparency mandates on welfare data, Differential subsidies for higher-welfare systems using PLF responsibly

answers.question: How to measure welfare?Critics worry that the metrics tracked by PLF may not actually correspond with the welfare of animals. How exactly welfare is defined & measured makes all the difference. What risks might there be if there is a “gap” between welfare & the proxy measures that are tracked by PLF?
answers.answer: Animal welfare is a multidimensional concept, encompassing not just physical health but also psychological wellbeing, including the ability to express natural behaviors, experience comfort, and avoid suffering. Precision Livestock Farming (PLF), however, typically tracks proxy metrics such as body temperature, feeding frequency, or movement patterns, measurable indicators that are often selected for convenience or economic relevance rather than ethical completeness. If there is a gap between true welfare and these proxies, several risks emerge. First, animals may appear “healthy” by sensor data while still experiencing chronic stress, boredom, fear, or social deprivation, harms that go undetected because they are harder to quantify. Second, reliance on narrow proxies may incentivize farms to optimize for metrics rather than wellbeing, reinforcing harmful systems as long as numbers “look good.” Third, public and regulatory trust could be eroded if technologies advertised as promoting welfare actually obscure suffering. Ultimately, if PLF systems reinforce an impoverished definition of welfare, they risk locking in technological standards that fail to protect sentient beings, thereby legitimizing exploitation under a veneer of scientific progress.
